items.text: **Donald John Trump** (born June 14, 1946) is the [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States|45th]] and current [[LINK|lang_en|President_of_the_United_States|President of the United States]], in office since January 20, 2017 [[CITE|30|https://web.archive.org/web/20180108164806/https://doc-10-a0-apps-viewer.googleusercontent.com/viewer/secure/pdf/3nb9bdfcv3e2h2k1cmql0ee9cvc5lole/5n928o2thhvsuu1akhmqmrafhmo5lp97/1515430050000/drive/*/ACFrOgCuRVD3ePAyXrIcoWsdY2vvaaXvJUvcYN0f011ItmUjCaE3TlVeKsmfSmTfPkUWZkHkkm9Qjz5mxolAfFWYOj6CEHk9vLp92zzAQHkLDc36RZCEOo4HqXCWP1s=?hash=e5m6708ku59bl5ocp8d9iosqjf825iqc&nonce=kau3fvo9kgs5k&print=true&user=*]] . Before entering politics, he was a businessman and television producer and host.

Trump was born in the [[LINK|lang_en|New_York_City|New York City]] borough of [[LINK|lang_en|Queens|Queens]]. He earned an economics degree from the [[LINK|lang_en|Wharton_School_of_the_University_of_Pennsylvania|Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]]. A third-generation businessman, Trump followed in the footsteps of his grandmother [[LINK|lang_en|Elizabeth_Christ_Trump|Elizabeth]] and father [[LINK|lang_en|Fred_Trump|Fred]] in running the family real estate company (now [[LINK|lang_en|The_Trump_Organization|The Trump Organization]]). He controlled it from 1971 until [[LINK|lang_en|Inauguration_of_Donald_Trump|his inauguration]] as president in January 2017, when he delegated company management to his sons [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_Jr.|Donald Jr.]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Eric_Trump|Eric]]. Trump primarily focused on building or renovating office towers, hotels, casinos, and golf courses. He has written or co-authored several books, including *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Art_of_the_Deal|The Art of the Deal]] *, and he produced and hosted the television show *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Apprentice_(U.S._TV_series)|The Apprentice]] * for 12 years. As of 2017, he was the 544th richest person in the world, with an estimated net worth of $3.5 billion.

Trump entered the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election,_2016|2016 presidential race]] as a [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_(United_States)|Republican]], and defeated sixteen opponents in the [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_presidential_primaries,_2016|primaries]]. Commentators described his political positions as [[LINK|lang_en|Populist|populist]], [[LINK|lang_en|Protectionism_in_the_United_States|protectionist]], and [[LINK|lang_en|American_nationalism|nationalist]]. His campaign received extensive [[LINK|lang_en|Earned_media|free media coverage]]; many of his public statements were controversial or false. Trump won the general election on November 8, 2016 against [[LINK|lang_en|Democratic_Party_(United_States)|Democratic]] opponent [[LINK|lang_en|Hillary_Clinton|Hillary Clinton]]. He became the [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_by_age|oldest]] and [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_by_net_worth|wealthiest]] person ever to assume the presidency, the first without [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_by_previous_experience|prior military or government service]], and [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_elections_in_which_the_winner_lost_the_popular_vote|the fifth]] to have won the election despite losing the [[LINK|lang_en|Popular_vote_(representative_democracy)|popular vote]]. His election and policies have sparked [[LINK|lang_en|Protests_against_Donald_Trump|numerous protests]].

Trump has sought, so far without success, to repeal and replace the [[LINK|lang_en|Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act|Affordable Care Act]]. He appointed [[LINK|lang_en|Neil_Gorsuch|Neil Gorsuch]] to the [[LINK|lang_en|Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States|Supreme Court]]. He ordered [[LINK|lang_en|Executive_Order_13780|a travel ban]] on citizens from several Muslim-majority countries, citing security concerns; the ban was partially implemented after [[LINK|lang_en|Legal_challenges_to_the_Trump_travel_ban|legal challenges]]. He withdrew the United States from the [[LINK|lang_en|Trans-Pacific_Partnership|Trans-Pacific Partnership]] and [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_withdrawal_from_the_Paris_Agreement|from the]] [[LINK|lang_en|Paris_Climate_Agreement|Paris Climate Agreement]], and undid parts of the [[LINK|lang_en|Cuban_Thaw|Cuban Thaw]]. After Trump [[LINK|lang_en|Dismissal_of_James_Comey|dismissed FBI Director James Comey]], the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Department_of_Justice|Justice Department]] appointed a [[LINK|lang_en|2017_Special_Counsel_investigation|special counsel to continue the investigation]] into potential [[LINK|lang_en|Links_between_Trump_associates_and_Russian_officials|links between Russia and Trump campaign associates]], and any related matters.
Family and personal life
Ancestry

Trump's ancestors originated from the German village of [[LINK|lang_en|Kallstadt|Kallstadt]], [[LINK|lang_en|Palatinate_(region)|Palatinate]], on his father's side, and from the [[LINK|lang_en|Outer_Hebrides|Outer Hebrides]] in Scotland on his mother's side. All his grandparents, and his mother, were born in Europe. His mother's grandfather was also christened "Donald".

Trump's paternal grandfather, [[LINK|lang_en|Frederick_Trump|Friedrich Trump]], first emigrated to the United States in 1885 at the age of 16, and became a citizen in 1892. He amassed a fortune operating boom-town restaurants and boarding houses in the Seattle area and the [[LINK|lang_en|Klondike,_Yukon|Klondike]] region of Canada during [[LINK|lang_en|Klondike_Gold_Rush|its gold rush]]. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] On a visit to Kallstadt, he met [[LINK|lang_en|Elizabeth_Christ_Trump|Elisabeth Christ]] and married her in 1902. The couple settled in New York permanently in 1905. Frederick died from [[LINK|lang_en|Influenza|influenza]] during the [[LINK|lang_en|1918_flu_pandemic|1918 pandemic]].

Donald's father, [[LINK|lang_en|Fred_Trump|Fred Trump]], was born in 1905 in [[LINK|lang_en|The_Bronx|the Bronx]]. Fred started working with his mother in real estate when he was 15, shortly after his father's death. Their company, Elizabeth Trump and Son, was primarily active in the [[LINK|lang_en|Boroughs_of_New_York_City|New York boroughs]] of [[LINK|lang_en|Queens|Queens]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Brooklyn|Brooklyn]]. Fred eventually built and sold thousands of houses, barracks and apartments. [[CITE|659|http://politico.com/magazine/story/2015/08/the-man-who-made-trump-who-he-is-121647]] The company later became [[LINK|lang_en|The_Trump_Organization|The Trump Organization]] after Donald Trump took over in 1971.

Donald's mother, [[LINK|lang_en|Mary_Anne_MacLeod_Trump|Mary Anne]], was born in [[LINK|lang_en|Tong,_Lewis|Tong, Lewis]], Scotland. At age 18 in 1930, she emigrated to New York, where she worked as a maid. [[CITE|763|http://newyorker.com/news/news-desk/donald-trumps-immigrant-mother]] Fred and Mary were married in 1936 and raised their family in Queens. [[CITE|763|http://newyorker.com/news/news-desk/donald-trumps-immigrant-mother]] [[CITE|978|http://newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-ancestral-german-home-of-the-trumps]]

Donald's uncle [[LINK|lang_en|John_G._Trump|John Trump]] was an electrical engineer, physicist, and inventor. He was also a professor at [[LINK|lang_en|Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology|MIT]] from 1936 to 1973. During [[LINK|lang_en|World_War_II|World War II]], he was involved in radar research for the Allies and helped design X-ray machines that were used to treat cancer. [[CITE|1071|http://newyorker.com/news/amy-davidson/donald-trumps-nuclear-uncle]]
Early life and education

Donald Trump was born on June 14, 1946, at the Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, [[LINK|lang_en|Queens|Queens]], New York City. He was the fourth of five children born to [[LINK|lang_en|Fred_Trump|Frederick Trump]] (1905–1999) and [[LINK|lang_en|Mary_Anne_Trump|Mary Anne Trump]] (née MacLeod, 1912–2000). [[CITE|328|http://foxnews.com/projects/pdf/20110328125536753.pdf]] His siblings are [[LINK|lang_en|Maryanne_Trump_Barry|Maryanne]] (b. 1937), Fred Jr. (1938–1981), Elizabeth (b. 1942), and Robert (b. 1948).

Trump grew up in the [[LINK|lang_en|Jamaica_Estates|Jamaica Estates]] neighborhood of Queens. He attended the [[LINK|lang_en|Kew-Forest_School|Kew-Forest School]] from kindergarten through seventh grade. At age 13, he enrolled in the [[LINK|lang_en|New_York_Military_Academy|New York Military Academy]], a private boarding school, after his parents discovered that he had made frequent trips into Manhattan without their permission. [[CITE|352|https://washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/young-donald-trump-military-school/2016/06/22/f0b3b164-317c-11e6-8758-d58e76e11b12_story.html]]

In August 1964, Trump began his higher education at [[LINK|lang_en|Fordham_University|Fordham University]]. [[CITE|464|https://bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2015/08/28/donald-trump-was-bombastic-even-wharton-business-school/3FO0j1uS5X6S8156yH3YhL/story.html]] After two years, he transferred to the [[LINK|lang_en|Wharton_School_of_the_University_of_Pennsylvania|Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]], because it offered one of the few real-estate studies departments in United States academia at the time. [[CITE|464|https://bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2015/08/28/donald-trump-was-bombastic-even-wharton-business-school/3FO0j1uS5X6S8156yH3YhL/story.html]]

In addition to his father, Trump was inspired by Manhattan developer [[LINK|lang_en|William_Zeckendorf|William Zeckendorf]], vowing to be "even bigger and better". While at Wharton, he worked at the family business, Elizabeth Trump and Son, graduating in May 1968 with a [[LINK|lang_en|Bachelor_of_Science#North_America|Bachelor of Science degree]] in economics. [[CITE|464|https://bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2015/08/28/donald-trump-was-bombastic-even-wharton-business-school/3FO0j1uS5X6S8156yH3YhL/story.html]] [[CITE|933|https://www.wharton.upenn.edu/wp-content/uploads/125anniversaryissue/trump.html]] [[CITE|1030|http://www.archives.upenn.edu/primdocs/upg/upg7/upg7_1968.pdf]]

Trump did not enlist or get drafted during the [[LINK|lang_en|Vietnam_War|Vietnam War]]. [[CITE|186|http://cbsnews.com/news/donald-trump-avoided-vietnam-with-deferments-records-show]] While in college from 1964 to 1968, he obtained four student deferments. [[CITE|121|http://worldcat.org/issn/0458-3035]] In 1966, he was deemed fit for service based upon a military medical examination, and in 1968 was briefly classified as fit by a local draft board. In September of that year, he was given a [[LINK|lang_en|Selective_Service_System|medical deferment]], which he later attributed to [[LINK|lang_en|Calcaneal_spur|heel spurs]]. [[CITE|1097|https://washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/questions-linger-about-trumps-draft-deferments-during-vietnam-war/2015/07/21/257677bc-2fdd-11e5-8353-1215475949f4_story.html]] In 1969, he received a high number in the [[LINK|lang_en|Draft_lottery_(1969)|draft lottery]], which gave him a low probability to be called to military service. [[CITE|1097|https://washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/questions-linger-about-trumps-draft-deferments-during-vietnam-war/2015/07/21/257677bc-2fdd-11e5-8353-1215475949f4_story.html]] [[CITE|339|http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trumps-vietnam-draft-records-secret-documents-deferments/story?id=13492639]] [[CITE|118|http://worldcat.org/issn/0362-4331]]
Family
Trump has five children by three marriages, as well as nine grandchildren.

[[CITE|564|https://usatoday.com/story/life/2017/09/12/eric-and-lara-trump-announce-birth-son-potus-ninth-grandchild/658130001]] [[CITE|919|http://foxnews.com/politics/2016/03/27/trumps-daughter-ivanka-gives-birth-to-third-child.html]] His first two marriages ended in widely publicized divorces.

Trump was 30 years old when he married his first wife, Czech model [[LINK|lang_en|Ivana_Zelníčková|Ivana Zelníčková]] in 1977 at the [[LINK|lang_en|Marble_Collegiate_Church|Marble Collegiate Church]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Manhattan|Manhattan]] in a ceremony performed by the Reverend [[LINK|lang_en|Norman_Vincent_Peale|Norman Vincent Peale]]. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|874|https://nytimes.com/2016/09/06/nyregion/donald-trump-marble-collegiate-church-norman-vincent-peale.html]] They had three children: [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_Jr.|Donald Jr.]] (b. 1977), [[LINK|lang_en|Ivanka_Trump|Ivanka]] (b. 1981), and [[LINK|lang_en|Eric_Trump|Eric]] (b. 1984). Ivana became a naturalized United States citizen in 1988. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] The couple divorced in 1992, following Trump's affair with actress [[LINK|lang_en|Marla_Maples|Marla Maples]]. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

In October 1993, Maples gave birth to Trump's daughter, who was named [[LINK|lang_en|Tiffany_Trump|Tiffany]] after high-end retailer [[LINK|lang_en|Tiffany_&_Company|Tiffany & Company]]. [[CITE|226|http://slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2016/07/20/tiffany_trump_s_sad_vague_rnc_speech.html]] Maples and Trump were married two months later on December 20, 1993. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] They divorced in 1999, [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] and Tiffany was raised by Marla in California. [[CITE|468|https://nytimes.com/2016/10/02/fashion/tiffany-the-other-trump.html]]

On January 22, 2005, Trump married his third wife, Slovenian model [[LINK|lang_en|Melania_Knauss|Melania Knauss]], at [[LINK|lang_en|Bethesda-by-the-Sea|Bethesda-by-the-Sea]] Episcopal Church in [[LINK|lang_en|Palm_Beach,_Florida|Palm Beach, Florida]]. The ceremony was followed by a reception at Trump's [[LINK|lang_en|Mar-a-Lago|Mar-a-Lago]] estate. In 2006, Melania became a United States citizen [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] and on March 20 of that year gave birth to a son, Barron. [[CITE|347|https://books.google.com/books?id=YEdwW78QWj0C&pg=PA251]] [[CITE|426|http://cnn.com/2013/07/04/us/donald-trump-fast-facts]] Melania became [[LINK|lang_en|First_Lady_of_the_United_States|First Lady of the United States]] upon Trump's inauguration as the nation's 45th president in January 2017. [[CITE|897|https://nytimes.com/2016/11/09/us/politics/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-president.html]]

Upon his inauguration as president, Trump delegated the management of his real estate business to his two adult sons, Eric and Don Jr. His daughter Ivanka resigned from The Trump Organization and moved to Washington with her husband [[LINK|lang_en|Jared_Kushner|Jared Kushner]]. She serves as an assistant to the president, [[CITE|1031|https://economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/03/family-affair]] and he is a [[LINK|lang_en|Senior_Advisor_to_the_President_of_the_United_States|Senior Advisor]] in the White House. [[CITE|1117|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/21/us/politics/donald-trump-jared-kushner-justice-department.html]]

Trump's elder sister, [[LINK|lang_en|Maryanne_Trump_Barry|Maryanne Barry]], is an inactive [[LINK|lang_en|Federal_Appeals_Court|Federal Appeals Court]] judge on the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Court_of_Appeals_for_the_Third_Circuit|Third Circuit]]. [[CITE|123|https://law360.com/articles/888127/3rd-circ-judge-trump-s-sister-stops-hearing-cases]]

caption.text: Donald Trump is [[LINK|lang_en|Inauguration_of_Donald_Trump|sworn in]] as president on January 20, 2017: Trump, wife [[LINK|lang_en|Melania_Trump|Melania]], son [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_Jr.|Donald Jr.]], son [[LINK|lang_en|Family_of_Donald_Trump#Barron_Trump|Barron]], daughter [[LINK|lang_en|Ivanka_Trump|Ivanka]], son [[LINK|lang_en|Eric_Trump|Eric]], and daughter [[LINK|lang_en|Tiffany_Trump|Tiffany]]

items.text: Religion

Trump's ancestors were [[LINK|lang_en|Lutheran|Lutheran]] on his father's side in Germany and [[LINK|lang_en|Presbyterianism#Scotland|Presbyterian]] on his mother's side in Scotland. [[CITE|248|http://irishtimes.com/news/world/us/few-rooting-for-donald-trump-on-his-mother-s-scottish-island-1.2663636]] His parents married in a Manhattan Presbyterian church in 1936. As a child, he attended the [[LINK|lang_en|First_Presbyterian_Church_in_Jamaica|First Presbyterian Church]] in Jamaica, Queens, and had his [[LINK|lang_en|Confirmation|Confirmation]] there. [[CITE|874|https://nytimes.com/2016/09/06/nyregion/donald-trump-marble-collegiate-church-norman-vincent-peale.html]] In the 1970s, his family joined the [[LINK|lang_en|Marble_Collegiate_Church|Marble Collegiate Church]] (an affiliate of the [[LINK|lang_en|Reformed_Church_in_America|Reformed Church in America]]) in [[LINK|lang_en|Manhattan|Manhattan]]. [[CITE|473|https://washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/how-trump-got-religion--and-why-his-legendary-ministers-son-now-rejects-him/2016/01/21/37bae16e-bb02-11e5-829c-26ffb874a18d_story.html]] The pastor at that church, [[LINK|lang_en|Norman_Vincent_Peale|Norman Vincent Peale]], author of *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Power_of_Positive_Thinking|The Power of Positive Thinking]] * and *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Art_of_Living|The Art of Living]] *, ministered to Trump's family and mentored him until Peale's death in 1993. [[CITE|473|https://washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/how-trump-got-religion--and-why-his-legendary-ministers-son-now-rejects-him/2016/01/21/37bae16e-bb02-11e5-829c-26ffb874a18d_story.html]] Trump, who is Presbyterian, [[CITE|880|http://politico.com/story/2016/12/trump-religious-dealmaking-dividends-232277]] [[CITE|133|http://humanevents.com/article.php?id=42268]] has cited Peale and his works during interviews when asked about the role of religion in his personal life. [[CITE|473|https://washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/how-trump-got-religion--and-why-his-legendary-ministers-son-now-rejects-him/2016/01/21/37bae16e-bb02-11e5-829c-26ffb874a18d_story.html]]

Trump receives [[LINK|lang_en|Holy_Communion|Holy Communion]], but he has said that he does not ask God for forgiveness. He stated: "I think if I do something wrong, I just try and make it right. I don't bring God into that picture....I guess that [Communion] is a form of asking for forgiveness”. [[CITE|741|http://cnn.com/2015/07/18/politics/trump-has-never-sought-forgiveness]] On the [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_presidential_campaign,_2016|campaign trail]], Trump has referred to *[[LINK|lang_en|Trump:_The_Art_of_the_Deal|The Art of the Deal]] * as his second favorite book after the Bible, saying, "Nothing beats the Bible." In a 2016 speech to [[LINK|lang_en|Liberty_University|Liberty University]], he referred to "[[LINK|lang_en|Second_Corinthians|2 Corinthians]]" (pronounced "Second Corinthians") as "Two Corinthians", eliciting chuckles from the audience. [[CITE|141|http://cnn.com/2016/01/20/politics/donald-trump-tony-perkins-sarah-palin/index.html]] [[CITE|222|http://telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/us-election/12107003/Donald-Trump-faces-questions-over-Two-Corinthians.html]] *The New York Times* reported that [[LINK|lang_en|Evangelicalism|Evangelical Christians]] nationwide thought "that his heart was in the right place, that his intentions for the country were pure". [[CITE|340|https://nytimes.com/2016/01/19/us/politics/evangelicals-see-donald-trump-as-man-of-conviction-if-not-faith.html]]

Trump has had associations with a number of Christian spiritual leaders, including Florida pastor [[LINK|lang_en|Paula_White|Paula White]], who has been called his "closest spiritual confidant." [[CITE|470|http://cnn.com/2016/10/21/politics/trump-religion-gospel]] In 2015, he received a blessing from [[LINK|lang_en|Greek_Orthodox_Church|Greek Orthodox]] priest [[LINK|lang_en|Emmanuel_Lemelson|Emmanuel Lemelson]] [[CITE|558|http://video.foxbusiness.com/v/4598495569001]] and in 2016, he released a list of his religious advisers, including [[LINK|lang_en|James_Dobson|James Dobson]], [[LINK|lang_en|Jerry_Falwell_Jr.|Jerry Falwell Jr.]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ralph_Reed|Ralph Reed]] and others. [[CITE|666|https://donaldjtrump.com/press-releases/trump-campaign-announces-evangelical-executive-advisory-board]] Referring to his daughter Ivanka's [[LINK|lang_en|Conversion_to_Judaism|conversion to Judaism]] before her marriage to [[LINK|lang_en|Jared_Kushner|Jared Kushner]], Trump said: "I have a Jewish daughter; and I am very honored by that." [[CITE|770|http://jewishvoiceny.com/index.php?Iteref=&catid=121%3Aspecial-features&id=10058%3Aalgemeiner-journal-jewish-100-gala-honors-donald-trump-joan-rivers-and-yuli-edelsterin&lang=en&option=com_content&view=article]]
Health

Trump's physician, [[LINK|lang_en|Harold_Bornstein|Harold Bornstein]], issued a 2016 medical report that showed Trump's blood pressure and liver and thyroid function to be in normal ranges. [[CITE|841|http://time.com/4495117/donald-trump-doctors-letter?xid=homepage]] [[CITE|930|https://nytimes.com/2016/09/19/us/politics/donald-trump-health.html]] It also showed that he is overweight and takes statins to lower his cholesterol. [[CITE|930|https://nytimes.com/2016/09/19/us/politics/donald-trump-health.html]] Trump has said that he has never smoked cigarettes or consumed drugs, including [[LINK|lang_en|Marijuana|marijuana]]. [[CITE|138|https://youtube.com/watch?v=0fN5OLqxNqc]] He also [[LINK|lang_en|Teetotalism|drinks no alcohol]]; this decision arose in part from watching his older brother Fred Jr. suffer from alcoholism that contributed to his early death in 1981. [[CITE|388|http://people.com/article/donald-trump-brother-fred-death-alcoholism]]
Wealth
Trump said that he began his career with "a small loan of one million dollars" from his father.

[[CITE|447|https://cnbc.com/2015/10/26/donald-trump-my-dad-gave-me-a-small-loan-of-1-million-to-get-started.html]] He appeared on the initial *[[LINK|lang_en|Forbes_400|Forbes 400]] * list of wealthy individuals in 1982 with an estimated $200 million fortune, including an "undefined" share of his parents' estate. During the late 1980s he became a billionaire, and made the *[[LINK|lang_en|The_World's_Billionaires|Forbes World's Billionaires]] * list for the first time in 1989, [[CITE|757|https://theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2011/04/weve-been-trying-figure-out-how-much-trump-worth-20-years/349875]] but he was absent from the *Forbes 400* list following business losses from 1990 to 1995; he reportedly borrowed from his siblings' trusts in 1993. His father's estate, valued at more than $20 million, was divided in 1999 among Trump, his three surviving siblings and their children.
When Trump announced his candidacy for the presidency on June 16, 2015, he released a one-page financial summary that stated a net worth of $8,737,540,000.

The following month, he filed a 92-page [[LINK|lang_en|Federal_Election_Commission|Federal Election Commission]] (FEC) financial disclosure form [[CITE|181|https://washingtonpost.com/wp-stat/graphics/politics/trump-archive/docs/trump-fec-financial-disclosure-2015.pdf]] and declared his net worth was "in excess of ten billion dollars". [[CITE|889|https://donaldjtrump.com/images/uploads/DJT_PFD_Statement_(1).pdf]] In his presidential announcement speech, he said "I'm really rich", and said this would make him less indebted to large campaign donors. [[CITE|503|http://npr.org/sections/itsallpolitics/2015/06/17/415003043/the-problem-with-donald-trumps-one-page-summary-on-his-wealth]] *Forbes* called his net worth estimate "a whopper", setting their own estimate at $4.1 billion in 2015. Trump valued his "properties under development" at $293 million; *Forbes* said they could not evaluate those deals, and booked them for $0. [[CITE|1056|https://web.archive.org/web/20150505203058/https://www.forbes.com/profile/donald-trump]] Trump's 2015 FEC disclosure reported $362 million in total income for the year 2014. [[CITE|889|https://donaldjtrump.com/images/uploads/DJT_PFD_Statement_(1).pdf]]
After Trump made controversial remarks about illegal immigrants in 2015, he lost business contracts with several companies; this reduced his *Forbes* estimate by $125 million.
Consumer boycotts and reduced bookings may have further affected his brand value during the presidential campaign.

[[CITE|262|https://nytimes.com/2016/10/18/us/politics/donald-trump-brand-reaction.html]] [[CITE|400|http://time.com/money/4349354/donald-trump-hurt-hotel-bookings]] [[CITE|474|https://cnbc.com/2016/08/04/trump-hotels-and-casino-traffic-has-taken-a-huge-hit-since-trump-started-running-for-president-commentary.html]] Trump's 104-page FEC disclosure in May 2016 [[CITE|729|http://money.cnn.com/2016/05/18/news/trump-finances]] still claimed a total wealth over $10 billion, unchanged from 2015. [[CITE|181|https://washingtonpost.com/wp-stat/graphics/politics/trump-archive/docs/trump-fec-financial-disclosure-2015.pdf]] The release of the [[LINK|lang_en|Access_Hollywood_tape_recordings|Access Hollywood tapes]] in October 2016 put further pressure on his brand, [[CITE|700|https://cnbc.com/2016/10/10/tape-release-further-erodes-trump-brand-survey.html]] but real estate experts predicted a positive rebound after he was elected. [[CITE|780|http://marketwatch.com/story/trump-branded-properties-are-poised-for-a-rebound-2016-11-13]]

In its 2017 billionaires' ranking, *[[LINK|lang_en|Forbes|Forbes]] * estimated Trump's net worth at $3.5 billion (544th in the world, 201st in the U.S.) [[CITE|156|https://forbes.com/profile/donald-trump?list=billionaires]] making him one of the [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_richest_American_politicians|richest politicians in American history]]. These estimates fluctuate from year to year, and among various analysts. In July 2016 *[[LINK|lang_en|Bloomberg_News|Bloomberg News]] * had pegged his wealth at $3 billion, calling it an increase thanks to his presidential nomination, [[CITE|864|https://bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-07-19/trump-is-richer-in-property-and-deeper-in-debt-in-new-valuation]] whereas *Forbes* had ranked him 324th in the world (113th in the U.S.) with $4.5 billion just a few months earlier. [[CITE|978|http://newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-ancestral-german-home-of-the-trumps]] The discrepancies among these estimates and with Trump's own figures stem mainly from the uncertain values of [[LINK|lang_en|Real_estate_appraisal|appraised property]] and of his [[LINK|lang_en|Personal_brand|personal brand]]. [[CITE|864|https://bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-07-19/trump-is-richer-in-property-and-deeper-in-debt-in-new-valuation]] [[CITE|978|http://newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-ancestral-german-home-of-the-trumps]]
In November 2017 the Trump Organization's revenue was suggested, by federal filings, to be $600m-$700m rather than the $9.5b previously claimed by the organization.
[[CITE|978|http://newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-ancestral-german-home-of-the-trumps]]
Business career
Real estate

Trump started his career at his father's real estate development company, Elizabeth Trump and Son, which owned middle-class rental housing in New York City's outer [[LINK|lang_en|Borough_(New_York_City)|boroughs]], but also had business elsewhere. For example, during his [[LINK|lang_en|Undergraduate_education|undergraduate study]], Trump joined his father Fred in successfully revitalizing the foreclosed Swifton Village apartment complex in [[LINK|lang_en|Cincinnati|Cincinnati]], Ohio, boosting the occupancy rate from 66% to 100%. [[CITE|978|http://newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-ancestral-german-home-of-the-trumps]] [[CITE|325|http://parade.com/articles/editions/2004/edition_11-14-2004/in_step_with_0]]

When his father became chairman of the board in 1971, Trump was promoted to president of the company and renamed it [[LINK|lang_en|The_Trump_Organization|The Trump Organization]]. [[CITE|978|http://newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-ancestral-german-home-of-the-trumps]] In 1973, he and his father [[LINK|lang_en|Legal_affairs_of_Donald_Trump#Lawsuits_1970–1999|drew wider attention]] when the [[LINK|lang_en|Justice_Department_(United_States)|Justice Department]] contended that the organization systematically discriminated against African Americans wishing to rent apartments rather than merely screening out people based on low income as the Trumps stated. Under an agreement reached in 1975, the Trumps made no admission of wrongdoing, and made the [[LINK|lang_en|Urban_League|Urban League]] an intermediary for qualified minority applicants. [[CITE|814|https://washingtonpost.com/politics/inside-the-governments-racial-bias-case-against-donald-trumps-company-and-how-he-fought-it/2016/01/23/fb90163e-bfbe-11e5-bcda-62a36b394160_story.html]] His adviser and attorney during (and after) that period was [[LINK|lang_en|Roy_Cohn|Roy Cohn]], who responded to attacks by counterattacking with maximum force, and who valued both positive and negative publicity, which were attitudes that Trump appreciated.

caption.text: The President and First Lady at the Liberty Ball on [[LINK|lang_en|Inauguration_of_Donald_Trump|Inauguration Day]]

items.text: Manhattan developments
In 1978, Trump consummated his first major real estate deal in Manhattan when he purchased a half-share in the decrepit Commodore Hotel.

The purchase was largely funded by a $70 million construction loan that was jointly guaranteed by Fred Trump and the [[LINK|lang_en|Hyatt|Hyatt]] hotel chain. Designed by architect [[LINK|lang_en|Der_Scutt|Der Scutt]], the project leveraged competing interests and by taking advantage of tax breaks. After remodeling, the hotel reopened as the [[LINK|lang_en|Grand_Hyatt_New_York|Grand Hyatt Hotel]], located next to [[LINK|lang_en|Grand_Central_Terminal|Grand Central Terminal]].

Also in 1978, Trump finished negotiations to develop [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Tower|Trump Tower]], a 58-story, 202-meter (663-foot) skyscraper in [[LINK|lang_en|Midtown_Manhattan|Midtown Manhattan]], which *The New York Times* attributed to his "persistence" and "skills as a negotiator". [[CITE|1071|http://newyorker.com/news/amy-davidson/donald-trumps-nuclear-uncle]] To make way for the new building, a crew of undocumented Polish workers demolished an old [[LINK|lang_en|Bonwit_Teller|Bonwit Teller]] store, including [[LINK|lang_en|Art_deco|art deco]] features that had initially been marked for preservation. The building was completed in 1983 and houses both the primary [[LINK|lang_en|Penthouse_apartment|penthouse]] [[LINK|lang_en|Condominium|condominium]] residence of Trump and the headquarters of The Trump Organization. [[CITE|292|https://nytimes.com/2016/12/09/nyregion/donald-trump-new-york-protests.html]] Architectural critic [[LINK|lang_en|Paul_Goldberger|Paul Goldberger]] said in 1983 that he was surprised to find the tower's atrium was "the most pleasant interior public space to be completed in New York in some years". [[CITE|414|https://nytimes.com/1983/04/04/arts/architecture-atrium-of-trump-tower-is-a-pleasant-surprise.html]] Trump Tower was the setting of the NBC television show *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Apprentice_(U.S._TV_series)|The Apprentice]] * and includes a fully functional television studio set. [[CITE|1071|http://newyorker.com/news/amy-davidson/donald-trumps-nuclear-uncle]]

Repairs on [[LINK|lang_en|Central_Park|Central Park]]'s [[LINK|lang_en|Wollman_Rink|Wollman Rink]] begun in 1980 by a [[LINK|lang_en|General_contractor|general contractor]] who was unconnected to Trump. Despite an anticipated two and a half year construction timeframe, the repairs remained incomplete in 1986. Trump took over the project, completed it in three months for $1.95 million, $775,000 less than the initial budget. He operated the rink for a year with most profits going to charity and public work projects, [[CITE|617|http://nytimes.com/1987/04/01/nyregion/trump-reports-large-profit-from-wollman-rink.html]] in exchange for the rink's [[LINK|lang_en|Concession_(contract)|concession]] rights. [[CITE|706|https://bloomberg.com/politics/features/2015-09-29/a-1980s-new-york-city-battle-explains-donald-trump-s-candidacy]]

In 1988 Trump acquired the [[LINK|lang_en|Plaza_Hotel|Plaza Hotel]] in Manhattan for a record-setting $407 million and asked his wife Ivana to manage its operation. Trump invested $50 million to restore the building, which he called "the Mona Lisa". According to hotel expert Thomas McConnell, the Trumps boosted it from a three-star to a four-star ranking and sold it in 1995, by which time Ivana was no longer involved. [[CITE|869|https://nytimes.com/1995/04/12/business/trump-is-selling-plaza-hotel-to-saudi-and-asian-investors.html]]

In 1994, Trump became involved with a building on [[LINK|lang_en|Columbus_Circle|Columbus Circle]] that was swaying in the wind. He began a reconstruction project that stopped the swaying and gave the building a full makeover. [[CITE|941|https://nytimes.com/1994/07/17/realestate/for-a-troubled-building-a-new-twist.html?pagewanted=all]] [[CITE|1017|https://nytimes.com/1995/06/21/nyregion/trump-tries-convert-50-s-style-into-90-s-gold-makeover-starts-columbus-circle.html]] Trump thereafter owned commercial space in that 44-story mixed-use tower (hotel and condominium), which he named [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_International_Hotel_and_Tower_(New_York)|Trump International Hotel and Tower]].

In 1996, Trump acquired the Bank of Manhattan Trust Building, which was a vacant seventy-one story skyscraper on [[LINK|lang_en|Wall_Street|Wall Street]] that had briefly been the [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_tallest_buildings|tallest building in the world]] when it was completed in 1930. After an extensive renovation, the high-rise was renamed the Trump Building at [[LINK|lang_en|40_Wall_Street|40 Wall Street]].

In 1997, he began construction on [[LINK|lang_en|Riverside_South,_Manhattan|Riverside South]], which he dubbed [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Place|Trump Place]], a multi-building development along the [[LINK|lang_en|Hudson_River|Hudson River]]. The project encountered delays the following year because a subcontracter had to replace defective concrete. [[CITE|139|https://nytimes.com/1998/01/16/nyregion/order-that-halted-work-on-trump-project-is-lifted.html]] [[CITE|122|http://classmates.com/yearbooks/New-York-Military-Academy/32008]] He and the other investors in the project ultimately sold their interest for $1.8 billion in 2005 in what was then the biggest residential sale in the history of New York City. [[CITE|122|http://classmates.com/yearbooks/New-York-Military-Academy/32008]]

From 1994 to 2002, Trump owned a 50% share of the [[LINK|lang_en|Empire_State_Building|Empire State Building]]. He would have renamed it "Trump Empire State Building Tower Apartments" if he had been able to boost his share. [[CITE|486|http://crainsnewyork.com/article/20160417/real_estate/160419898/the-deal-that-marked-donald-trumps-turn-from-new-york-real-estate-and-led-him-to-find-other-ways-to-remain-in-the-public-eye]]

In 2001, Trump completed [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_World_Tower|Trump World Tower]], which was across from the [[LINK|lang_en|Headquarters_of_the_United_Nations|headquarters of the United Nations]]. For a while, the structure was the [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_tallest_residential_buildings_in_the_world|tallest all-residential tower in the world]]. [[CITE|786|http://emporis.com/en/wm/bu?id=100377]] In 2002, Trump acquired the former Hotel Delmonico, which was renovated and reopened in 2004 as the [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Park_Avenue|Trump Park Avenue]]; the building consisted of 35 stories of luxury condominiums. Meanwhile, he continued to own millions of square feet of other prime [[LINK|lang_en|Manhattan|Manhattan]] real estate. [[CITE|122|http://classmates.com/yearbooks/New-York-Military-Academy/32008]]

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_International_Hotel_Las_Vegas|Trump International Hotel Las Vegas]], with gold infused glass [[CITE|1068|http://articles.latimes.com/2011/apr/30/nation/la-na-0430-trump-vegas-20110430]]

items.text: Palm Beach estate

In 1985, Trump acquired the historic [[LINK|lang_en|Mar-a-Lago|Mar-a-Lago]] estate in [[LINK|lang_en|Palm_Beach,_Florida|Palm Beach, Florida]] for $5 million plus $3 million for the home's furnishings. The home was built in the 1920s by heiress and socialite [[LINK|lang_en|Marjorie_Merriweather_Post|Marjorie Merriweather Post]], who envisioned the house as a future winter retreat for American presidents.

Trump's initial offer of $28 million had been rejected, and he was able to get the property at the much lower price by purchasing separate beachfront property and threatening to build a house on it that would block Mar-a-Lago's ocean view.
In addition to using the estate as a home, Trump also turned it into a private club open to everyone who could afford the initiation fee of $100,000 plus annual dues.

In 1986, Trump acquired a foreclosed 33-story, twin-tower condominium complex in nearby [[LINK|lang_en|West_Palm_Beach,_Florida|West Palm Beach]] for $40 million. Auto CEO [[LINK|lang_en|Lee_Iacocca|Lee Iacocca]] invested in three of the condos. Trump spruced up the complex's public areas and heavily promoted the property for years, but selling the units proved difficult, and the deal turned out to be unprofitable.
Atlantic City casinos

[[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey|New Jersey]] legalized casino gambling in 1977, and the following year Trump was in [[LINK|lang_en|Atlantic_City,_New_Jersey|Atlantic City, New Jersey]], to explore how he might get involved in a new business venture. Seven years later, [[LINK|lang_en|Harrah's_at_Trump_Plaza|Harrah's at Trump Plaza]] hotel and casino opened there, built by Trump with financing from [[LINK|lang_en|Holiday_Inn|Holiday Corporation]], which also managed the operation. Renamed "Trump Plaza" soon after it opened, it was at the time the tallest building in Atlantic City. The casino's poor financial results exacerbated disagreements between Trump and Holiday Corp., which led to Trump's paying $70 million in May 1986 to buy out their interest in the property. [[CITE|1063|https://nytimes.com/1986/09/05/business/company-news-trump-stake-in-holiday.html]] [[CITE|71|https://nytimes.com/1986/11/13/business/holiday-corp-plans-restructuring.html]] Trump also acquired a partially completed building in Atlantic City from the [[LINK|lang_en|Hilton_Worldwide|Hilton Corporation]] for $320 million; when completed in 1985, that hotel and casino became [[LINK|lang_en|Golden_Nugget_Atlantic_City|Trump Castle]], and Trump's wife, [[LINK|lang_en|Ivana_Trump|Ivana]], managed that property until Trump transferred her in 1988 to run the Trump Plaza Hotel in New York.

Also in 1988, Trump acquired his third casino in Atlantic City, the [[LINK|lang_en|Taj_Mahal_casino|Taj Mahal]] (then halfway through construction), through a complex transaction with television host and entertainer [[LINK|lang_en|Merv_Griffin|Merv Griffin]] as well as the resort and casino company [[LINK|lang_en|Resorts_International|Resorts International]]. In October 1989, three of his top Atlantic City executives were killed in a helicopter accident, which both stymied and delayed the planned opening of the Taj Mahal. The Taj finally opened in April 1990 and was built at a total cost of $1.1 billion, which at the time made it the most expensive casino ever. [[CITE|420|https://nytimes.com/1990/04/08/business/trump-s-taj-open-at-last-with-a-scary-appetite.html]] [[CITE|520|https://pbs.org/newshour/rundown/new-owner-of-trumps-taj-mahal-wants-to-make-casino-great-again]] The project was financed with $675 million in [[LINK|lang_en|Junk_bonds|junk bonds]] [[CITE|50|http://upi.com/Archives/1991/04/09/Trump-reaches-agreement-with-bondholders-on-Taj-Mahal/7261671169600]] and was a major gamble by Trump. The project underwent [[LINK|lang_en|Debt_restructuring|debt restructuring]] the following year, [[CITE|187|http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-filed-bankruptcy-times/story?id=13419250]] leaving Trump with 50% ownership. He also sold his 282-foot (86 m) [[LINK|lang_en|Megayacht|megayacht]], the *[[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Princess|Trump Princess]] *, which had been indefinitely docked in Atlantic City while leased to his casinos for use by wealthy gamblers. [[CITE|451|http://people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20122177,00.html]]

In 1995, Trump founded [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Hotels_&_Casino_Resorts|Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts]] (THCR), which assumed ownership of Trump Plaza, Trump Castle, and the [[LINK|lang_en|Majestic_Star_II|Trump Casino]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Gary,_Indiana|Gary, Indiana]]. [[CITE|1119|https://nytimes.com/1995/06/07/business/trump-plaza-casino-stock-trades-today-on-big-board.html]] THCR purchased Taj Mahal in 1996 and underwent bankruptcy restructuring in 2004 and 2009, leaving Trump with 10% ownership in the Trump Taj Mahal and other Trump casino properties. [[CITE|512|http://phillymag.com/news/2015/08/16/donald-trump-atlantic-city-empire]] From mid 1995 until early 2009, he served as chairman of the [[LINK|lang_en|Public_company|publicly-traded]] THCR organization—which was renamed Trump Entertainment Resorts—and served as CEO from mid 2000 to mid 2005. [[CITE|640|http://fortune.com/2016/03/10/trump-hotel-casinos-pay-failure]]

During the 1990s, Trump's casino ventures faced competition from [[LINK|lang_en|Native_American_gaming|Native American gaming]] at the [[LINK|lang_en|Foxwoods_Resort_Casino|Foxwoods]] casino located on an [[LINK|lang_en|Indian_reservation|Indian reservation]] in Connecticut, where it was exempt from the state's anti-gambling laws. Trump stated in 1993 that the casino owners did not look like real Indians to him or to other Indians. [[CITE|231|https://washingtonpost.com/national/donald-trumps-long-history-of-clashes-with-native-americans/2016/07/25/80ea91ca-3d77-11e6-80bc-d06711fd2125_story.html]] Subsequent to that well-publicized remark about the [[LINK|lang_en|Mashantucket_Pequot_Tribe|Mashantucket Pequot Tribe]], Trump became a key investor backing the [[LINK|lang_en|Eastern_Pequot_Tribal_Nation|Paucatuck Eastern Pequots]], who were also seeking state recognition. [[CITE|341|http://courant.com/politics/hc-trump-connecticut-years-20161013-story.html]]

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Central_Park|Central Park]]'s [[LINK|lang_en|Wollman_Rink|Wollman Rink]] after the Trump renovation

items.text: Golf courses

The Trump Organization operates many [[LINK|lang_en|Golf_course|golf courses]] and resorts in the United States and around the world. According to *[[LINK|lang_en|Golfweek|Golfweek]] *, Trump owns or manages about 18 golf courses. [[CITE|471|http://golfweek.com/news/2015/jun/16/donald-trump-us-president-2016-gop-golf-courses]] His personal financial disclosure with the [[LINK|lang_en|Federal_Elections_Commission|Federal Elections Commission]] stated that his golf and resort revenue for the year 2015 was roughly $382 million, [[CITE|181|https://washingtonpost.com/wp-stat/graphics/politics/trump-archive/docs/trump-fec-financial-disclosure-2015.pdf]] [[CITE|729|http://money.cnn.com/2016/05/18/news/trump-finances]] while his three European golf courses did not show a profit. [[CITE|864|https://bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-07-19/trump-is-richer-in-property-and-deeper-in-debt-in-new-valuation]]

In 2006, Trump bought 1,400 acres (570 ha), including the [[LINK|lang_en|Balmedie#Menie_Estate|Menie Estate]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Balmedie|Balmedie]], [[LINK|lang_en|Aberdeenshire,_Scotland|Aberdeenshire]], Scotland, and created a golf resort there. [[CITE|584|https://nytimes.com/2008/11/03/business/worldbusiness/03iht-trump.4.17483178.html]] Scottish supporters emphasized potential economic benefits, and opponents emphasized potential environmental harm to a [[LINK|lang_en|Site_of_Special_Scientific_Interest|Site of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSI). [[CITE|799|http://upstart.bizjournals.com/views/columns/the-windup/2008/02/22/Scottish-Clash-Over-Trump-Golf-Plan.html?page=all]] [[CITE|848|http://heraldscotland.com/news/home-news/first-look-at-trump-plan-for-world-s-best-course-1.1007048?54107=]] A spokesperson for the golf course has said 95% of the SSSI is untouched. [[CITE|982|http://seeker.com/amphtml/trump-dissolves-environmental-oversight-group-at-his-scottish-golf-cou-2209063040.html]] A 2011 independent documentary, *[[LINK|lang_en|You've_Been_Trumped|You've Been Trumped]] *, chronicled the golf resort's construction and struggles. [[CITE|915|http://rogerebert.com/reviews/youve-been-trumped-2012]] In 2015, [[LINK|lang_en|Aberdeen_Bay_Wind_Farm|an offshore windfarm]] being built within sight of the golf course prompted a legal challenge by Trump, which [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_International_Golf_Club_Scotland_Ltd_v_The_Scottish_Ministers|was dismissed]] by the [[LINK|lang_en|Supreme_Court_of_the_United_Kingdom|U.K. Supreme Court]]. In the wake of the 2008 recession, Trump greatly scaled back development of this property, and as of December 2016 Scottish officials were pushing for completion of the far larger development as originally approved. [[CITE|176|https://theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/dec/22/planners-reject-donald-trump-revised-plans-scottish-golf-resort]]

In April 2014, Trump purchased the [[LINK|lang_en|Turnberry_(golf_course)|Turnberry]] hotel and golf resort in [[LINK|lang_en|Ayrshire|Ayrshire]], Scotland, which hosted [[LINK|lang_en|The_Open_Championship|the Open Championship]] four times between 1977 and 2009. [[CITE|962|http://bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-27203208]] [[CITE|991|http://bbc.co.uk/sport/0/golf/27212412]] After extensive renovations and a remodeling of the course by golf architect Martin Ebert, Turnberry was re-opened in June 2016. [[CITE|472|http://golfdigest.com/story/donald-trumps-turnberry-a-review-of-the-presidential-nominees-renovated-ayrshire-course]]
Hotels outside New York

In the late 2000s and early 2010s, The Trump Organization expanded its footprint beyond New York with the co-development and management of [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_International_Hotel_and_Tower_(disambiguation)|hotel towers]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_International_Hotel_and_Tower_(Chicago)|Chicago]], [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_International_Hotel_Las_Vegas|Las Vegas]], [[LINK|lang_en|Old_Post_Office_Pavilion|Washington D.C.]], [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Ocean_Club_International_Hotel_and_Tower|Panama City]], [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_International_Hotel_and_Tower_(Toronto)|Toronto]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_International_Hotel_and_Tower_(Vancouver)|Vancouver]]. There are also Trump-branded buildings in Dubai, [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_International_Hotel_and_Tower_(Honolulu)|Honolulu]], Istanbul, Manila, Mumbai and in Indonesia. [[CITE|569|https://forbes.com/sites/jenniferwang/2017/03/20/these-foreign-businessmen-are-paying-donald-trump-the-most-money]]
Branding and licensing
Trump has marketed his name on a large number of building projects that are owned and operated by other people and companies.
He has also licensed his name for various commercial products and services.
In doing so, he achieved mixed success for himself, his partners, and investors in the projects.

[[CITE|840|http://nbcnews.com/storyline/bill-cosby-scandal/answer-no-bill-cosbys-hollywood-walk-fame-star-staying-put-n390836]] In 2011, *[[LINK|lang_en|Forbes|Forbes]]'* financial experts estimated the value of the Trump [[LINK|lang_en|Brand_equity|brand]] at $200 million. Trump disputed this valuation, saying his brand was worth about $3 billion.
Legal affairs and bankruptcies
As of 2016, Trump and his businesses had been involved in more than 3,500 state and federal legal actions.
He or one of his companies was the plaintiff in 1,900 cases and the defendant in 1,450.

With Trump or his company as plaintiff, more than half the cases have been against gamblers at his [[LINK|lang_en|Casino|casinos]] who had failed to pay off their debts. With Trump or his company as a defendant, the most common type of case involved personal injury cases at his hotels. In cases where there was a clear resolution, Trump's side won 451 times and lost 38. [[CITE|964|https://usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/06/01/donald-trump-lawsuits-legal-battles/84995854]] [[CITE|1033|http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/282008-trump-brags-about-winning-record-in-lawsuits]]

Trump has never filed for [[LINK|lang_en|Personal_bankruptcy|personal bankruptcy]], but his hotel and casino businesses have been declared [[LINK|lang_en|Chapter_11_bankruptcy|bankrupt]] six times between 1991 and 2009 in order to re-negotiate debt with banks and owners of stock and bonds. [[CITE|198|http://vanityfair.com/news/2015/06/donald-trump-companies-bankruptcy-atlantic-city]] [[CITE|225|http://ibtimes.com/donald-trump-questioned-his-bankruptcies-279717]] Because the businesses used [[LINK|lang_en|Chapter_11_bankruptcy|Chapter 11 bankruptcy]], they were allowed to operate while negotiations proceeded. Trump was quoted by *Newsweek* in 2011 saying, "I do play with the bankruptcy laws – they're very good for me" as a tool for trimming debt. [[CITE|274|http://publicintegrity.org/2011/05/05/4478/donald-trumps-lawsuits-could-turn-conservatives-who-embrace-tort-reform]] [[CITE|243|http://newsweek.com/kurtz-trump-backlash-66503]]

The six bankruptcies were the result of over-leveraged hotel and casino businesses in Atlantic City and New York: [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Taj_Mahal|Trump Taj Mahal]] (1991), [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Plaza_Hotel_and_Casino|Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino]] (1992), [[LINK|lang_en|Plaza_Hotel|Plaza Hotel]] (1992), [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Castle_Hotel_and_Casino|Trump Castle Hotel and Casino]] (1992), Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts (2004), and [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Entertainment_Resorts|Trump Entertainment Resorts]] (2009). [[CITE|365|http://nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-bankruptcy-math-doesn-t-add-n598376]] Trump said, "I've used the laws of this country to pare debt... We'll have the company. We'll throw it into a chapter. We'll negotiate with the banks. We'll make a fantastic deal. You know, it's like on *The Apprentice*. It's not personal. It's just business." [[CITE|187|http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-filed-bankruptcy-times/story?id=13419250]]

A 2016 analysis of Trump's business career by *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Economist|The Economist]] * concluded that his "... performance [from 1985 to 2016] has been mediocre compared with the stock market and property in New York", noting both his successes and bankruptcies. A subsequent analysis by *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Washington_Post|The Washington Post]] * concluded that "Trump is a mix of braggadocio, business failures, and real success", calling his casino bankruptcies the "most infamous flop" of his business career. [[CITE|680|https://washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2016/02/29/the-myth-and-the-reality-of-donald-trumps-business-empire]]
Side ventures

After Trump took over the family real estate firm in 1971 and renamed it [[LINK|lang_en|The_Trump_Organization|The Trump Organization]], he greatly expanded its real estate operations, and also ventured into numerous other business activities. The company eventually became the umbrella organization for several hundred individual business ventures and partnerships. [[CITE|1008|http://bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-33644498]]
Sports events

In September 1983, Trump purchased the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Jersey_Generals|New Jersey Generals]] —an [[LINK|lang_en|American_football|American football]] team that played in the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Football_League|United States Football League]] (USFL)—from oil magnate [[LINK|lang_en|J._Walter_Duncan|J. Walter Duncan]]. The USFL played three seasons during the spring and summer. After the 1985 season, the organization folded due to continuous financial difficulties, despite winning an [[LINK|lang_en|Antitrust|antitrust]] [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Football_League#USFL_v._NFL_lawsuit|lawsuit against the NFL]]. [[CITE|882|http://espn.com/espn/story/_/id/13255737/five-things-know-donald-trump-usfl-experience]]
Trump remained involved with other sports after the Generals folded; he operated golf courses in several countries.

[[CITE|882|http://espn.com/espn/story/_/id/13255737/five-things-know-donald-trump-usfl-experience]] At the [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Plaza_Hotel_and_Casino|Trump Plaza]] in Atlantic City, he hosted several boxing matches, which included [[LINK|lang_en|Mike_Tyson_vs._Michael_Spinks|Mike Tyson's 1988 heavyweight championship fight]] against [[LINK|lang_en|Michael_Spinks|Michael Spinks]]. He also acted as a financial advisor to [[LINK|lang_en|Mike_Tyson|Mike Tyson]]. In 1989 and 1990, Trump lent his name to the [[LINK|lang_en|Tour_de_Trump|Tour de Trump]] [[LINK|lang_en|Cycling_stage_race|cycling stage race]], which was an attempt to create an American equivalent of European races such as the [[LINK|lang_en|Tour_de_France|Tour de France]] or the [[LINK|lang_en|Giro_d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]]. [[CITE|366|http://politico.com/magazine/story/2016/04/donald-trump-2016-tour-de-trump-bike-race-213801]]
Miss Universe

From 1996 to 2015, Trump owned part or all of the [[LINK|lang_en|Miss_Universe|Miss Universe]] pageants. [[CITE|787|http://businessinsider.com/donald-trump-sells-miss-universe-img-2015-9]] The Miss Universe Pageants include [[LINK|lang_en|Miss_USA|Miss USA]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Miss_Teen_USA|Miss Teen USA]], and his management of this business involved his family members; for example, daughter [[LINK|lang_en|Ivanka_Trump|Ivanka]] once hosted Miss Teen USA. Trump hired the first female president of the Miss Universe business in 1997. He became dissatisfied with how [[LINK|lang_en|CBS|CBS]] scheduled the pageants, and took both Miss Universe and Miss USA to [[LINK|lang_en|NBC|NBC]] in 2002. [[CITE|712|https://nytimes.com/2002/06/22/business/three-beauty-pageants-leaving-cbs-for-nbc.html]] [[CITE|805|https://washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/2002/06/22/there-she-goes-pageants-move-to-nbc/2ba81b9a-bf67-4f3e-b8d6-1c2cc881ed19]]

In his 2015 U.S. presidential campaign kickoff speech, Trump made statements about [[LINK|lang_en|Illegal_immigration_to_the_United_States|illegal immigrants]] who crossed the border from Mexico. NBC then decided to end its business relationship with him and stated that it would no longer air the Miss Universe or Miss USA pageants on its networks. [[CITE|891|http://hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/nbc-cuts-ties-donald-trump-805706?facebook_20150629=]] In September 2015, Trump bought NBC's share of the Miss Universe Organization and became its sole owner for three days. He then sold the entire company to the WME/IMG talent agency.
Trump University

Trump University was a [[LINK|lang_en|For-profit_education|for-profit education]] company that was founded by Trump and his associates, Michael Sexton and Jonathan Spitalny. The company ran a real estate training program and charged between $1,500 and $35,000 per course. [[CITE|157|http://politico.com/magazine/story/2016/03/i-survived-trump-university-213710]] [[CITE|199|http://vanityfair.com/news/2014/01/trump-university-fraud-scandal]] In 2005, the operation was notified by New York State authorities that its use of the word "university" was misleading and violated state law. After a second such notification in 2010, the name of the company was changed to the "Trump Entrepreneurial Institute". [[CITE|293|http://huffingtonpost.com/davidhalperin/ny-court-refuses-to-dismi_b_9358360.html]] Trump was also found personally liable for failing to obtain a business license for the operation.
In 2013, the State of New York filed a $40 million civil suit alleging that Trump University made false statements and defrauded consumers.

[[CITE|293|http://huffingtonpost.com/davidhalperin/ny-court-refuses-to-dismi_b_9358360.html]] In addition, two class-action civil lawsuits were filed in federal court relating to Trump University; they named Trump personally as well as his companies.

During the [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_presidential_campaign,_2016|presidential campaign]], Trump criticized Judge [[LINK|lang_en|Gonzalo_P._Curiel|Gonzalo P. Curiel]] who oversaw those two cases, alleging bias in his rulings because of his Mexican heritage. [[CITE|905|https://nytimes.com/2016/06/04/us/politics/donald-trump-university-judge-gonzalo-curiel.html]] [[CITE|997|https://theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/06/donald-trump-gonzalo-curiel/485636]] Shortly after Trump won the presidency, the parties agreed to a settlement of all three pending cases, whereby Trump paid a total of $25 million and denied any wrongdoing.
Foundation

The Donald J. Trump Foundation is a U.S.-based [[LINK|lang_en|Private_foundation|private foundation]] [[CITE|49|https://projects.propublica.org/nonprofits/organizations/133404773]] established in 1988 for the initial purpose of giving away proceeds from the book *[[LINK|lang_en|Trump:_The_Art_of_the_Deal|Trump: The Art of the Deal]] *. [[CITE|933|https://www.wharton.upenn.edu/wp-content/uploads/125anniversaryissue/trump.html]] [[CITE|211|https://washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/09/01/trump-pays-irs-a-penalty-for-his-foundation-violating-rules-with-gift-to-florida-attorney-general]] The foundation's funds have mostly come from donors other than Trump, [[CITE|286|https://washingtonpost.com/politics/a-portrait-of-trump-the-donor-free-rounds-of-golf-but-no-personal-cash/2016/04/10/373b9b92-fb40-11e5-9140-e61d062438bb_story.html]] who has not given personally to the charity since 2008. [[CITE|286|https://washingtonpost.com/politics/a-portrait-of-trump-the-donor-free-rounds-of-golf-but-no-personal-cash/2016/04/10/373b9b92-fb40-11e5-9140-e61d062438bb_story.html]]
The foundation's tax returns show that it has given to health care and sports-related charities, as well as conservative groups.

[[CITE|933|https://www.wharton.upenn.edu/wp-content/uploads/125anniversaryissue/trump.html]] In 2009, for example, the foundation gave $926,750 to about 40 groups, with the biggest donations going to the [[LINK|lang_en|Arnold_Palmer_Hospital_for_Children#Arnold_Palmer_Medical_Center|Arnold Palmer Medical Center Foundation]] ($100,000), the [[LINK|lang_en|New_York–Presbyterian_Hospital|New York–Presbyterian Hospital]] ($125,000), the [[LINK|lang_en|Police_Athletic_League|Police Athletic League]] ($156,000), and the [[LINK|lang_en|Clinton_Foundation|Clinton Foundation]] ($100,000). [[CITE|697|https://washingtonpost.com/graphics/politics/2016-election/trump-charity-donations]] [[CITE|933|https://www.wharton.upenn.edu/wp-content/uploads/125anniversaryissue/trump.html]] From 2004 to 2014, the top donors to the foundation were [[LINK|lang_en|Vince_McMahon|Vince]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Linda_McMahon|Linda McMahon]] of [[LINK|lang_en|WWE|WWE]], who donated $5 million to the foundation after Trump appeared at [[LINK|lang_en|WrestleMania|WrestleMania]] in 2007. [[CITE|286|https://washingtonpost.com/politics/a-portrait-of-trump-the-donor-free-rounds-of-golf-but-no-personal-cash/2016/04/10/373b9b92-fb40-11e5-9140-e61d062438bb_story.html]] Linda McMahon later became Administrator of the [[LINK|lang_en|Small_Business_Administration|Small Business Administration]]. [[CITE|933|https://www.wharton.upenn.edu/wp-content/uploads/125anniversaryissue/trump.html]]

In 2016, investigations by *The Washington Post* uncovered several potential legal and ethical violations conducted by the charity, including alleged [[LINK|lang_en|Self-dealing|self-dealing]] and possible tax evasion. [[CITE|933|https://www.wharton.upenn.edu/wp-content/uploads/125anniversaryissue/trump.html]] After beginning an investigation into the foundation, the [[LINK|lang_en|New_York_State_Attorney_General|New York State Attorney General]]'s office notified the Trump Foundation that it was allegedly in violation of New York laws regarding charities, and ordered it to immediately cease its fundraising activities in New York. [[CITE|1037|http://cnn.com/2016/09/13/politics/eric-schneiderman-donald-trump-foundation]] [[CITE|933|https://www.wharton.upenn.edu/wp-content/uploads/125anniversaryissue/trump.html]] [[CITE|1030|http://www.archives.upenn.edu/primdocs/upg/upg7/upg7_1968.pdf]] A Trump spokesman called the investigation a "partisan hit job". [[CITE|1037|http://cnn.com/2016/09/13/politics/eric-schneiderman-donald-trump-foundation]] In response to mounting complaints, Trump's team announced in late December 2016 that the Trump Foundation would be dissolved to remove "even the appearance of any conflict with [his] role as President." [[CITE|1030|http://www.archives.upenn.edu/primdocs/upg/upg7/upg7_1968.pdf]] According to an IRS filing in November 2017, the foundation intends to shut down and distribute its assets (about $970,000) to other charities. However, a spokesperson for the New York Attorney General's office said the foundation cannot legally shut down until an ongoing investigation of the charity is completed. [[CITE|1030|http://www.archives.upenn.edu/primdocs/upg/upg7/upg7_1968.pdf]]
Post-election resignation
When Trump was elected president of the United States in November 2016, questions arose over how he would avoid conflicts of interest between his work in the White House and his business activities.

At a press conference on January 10, 2017, Trump said that he and his daughter [[LINK|lang_en|Ivanka_Trump|Ivanka]] would resign all roles with The Trump Organization, while his two adult sons [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_Jr.|Don Jr.]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Eric_Trump|Eric]] would run the business, together with Chief Financial Officer [[LINK|lang_en|Allen_Weisselberg|Allen Weisselberg]]. [[CITE|1030|http://www.archives.upenn.edu/primdocs/upg/upg7/upg7_1968.pdf]]
Trump retained his financial stake in the business.

[[CITE|1030|http://www.archives.upenn.edu/primdocs/upg/upg7/upg7_1968.pdf]] His attorney Sherri Dillon said that before the January 20 inauguration, Trump would put those business assets into a trust, which would hire an ethics advisor and a compliance counsel.

She added that [[LINK|lang_en|The_Trump_Organization|The Trump Organization]] would not enter any new foreign business deals, while continuing to pursue domestic opportunities. [[CITE|1030|http://www.archives.upenn.edu/primdocs/upg/upg7/upg7_1968.pdf]] As of April 2017, Trump companies owned more than 400 condo units and home lots in the United States, valued at over $250 million in total ($200,000 to $35 million each). [[CITE|1030|http://www.archives.upenn.edu/primdocs/upg/upg7/upg7_1968.pdf]]
Media career
*The Apprentice*

In 2003, Trump became the executive producer and host of the NBC [[LINK|lang_en|Reality_series|reality show]] *The Apprentice*, in which a group of competitors battled for a high-level management job in one of Trump's commercial enterprises. Contestants were successively "[[LINK|lang_en|Termination_of_employment|fired]]" and eliminated from the game. For the first year of the show, Trump earned $50,000 per episode (roughly $700,000 for the first season), but following the show's initial success, he was paid $1 million per episode. [[CITE|1030|http://www.archives.upenn.edu/primdocs/upg/upg7/upg7_1968.pdf]] In a July 2015 press release, Trump's campaign manager said that [[LINK|lang_en|NBCUniversal|NBCUniversal]] had paid him $213,606,575 for his 14 seasons hosting the show, [[CITE|889|https://donaldjtrump.com/images/uploads/DJT_PFD_Statement_(1).pdf]] although the network did not verify the statement. [[CITE|1030|http://www.archives.upenn.edu/primdocs/upg/upg7/upg7_1968.pdf]] In 2007, Trump received a star on the [[LINK|lang_en|Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame|Hollywood Walk of Fame]] for his contribution to television on *The Apprentice*. [[CITE|840|http://nbcnews.com/storyline/bill-cosby-scandal/answer-no-bill-cosbys-hollywood-walk-fame-star-staying-put-n390836]] [[CITE|764|http://thefiscaltimes.com/2015/07/10/15-Facts-You-Didn-t-Know-About-Donald-Trump]]

Along with British TV producer [[LINK|lang_en|Mark_Burnett|Mark Burnett]], Trump was hired as host of *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Celebrity_Apprentice|The Celebrity Apprentice]] *, in which celebrities compete to win money for their charities. While Trump and Burnett co-produced the show, Trump stayed in the forefront, deciding winners and "firing" losers. International versions of [[LINK|lang_en|The_Apprentice_(TV_series)|The Apprentice franchise]] were co-produced by Burnett and Trump.
On February 16, 2015, NBC announced that they would be renewing *The Apprentice* for a 15th season.

[[CITE|795|http://tvline.com/2015/02/16/celebrity-apprentice-renewed-season-15]] On February 27, Trump stated that he was "not ready" to sign on for another season because of the possibility of a presidential run.
[[CITE|827|http://unionleader.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20150227%2FNEWS0605%2F150229334%2F1010%2FArt]] Despite this, on March 18, NBC announced they were going ahead with production.

[[CITE|859|http://politico.com/blogs/media/2015/03/nbc-still-planning-for-apprentice-despite-donald-trumps-204171.html]] On June 29, after widespread negative reaction stemming from Trump's campaign announcement speech, NBC released a statement saying, "Due to the recent derogatory statements by Donald Trump regarding immigrants, NBCUniversal is ending its business relationship with Mr. Trump."
[[CITE|908|http://bgr.com/2015/06/29/nbc-fires-donald-trump-the-apprentice]]

After Trump's election campaign and presidential win led to his departure from the program, actor and former [[LINK|lang_en|Governor_of_California|California Governor]] [[LINK|lang_en|Arnold_Schwarzenegger|Arnold Schwarzenegger]] replaced Trump as host for the fifteenth season. [[CITE|377|http://ew.com/article/2015/09/14/arnold-schwarzenegger-replace-donald-Trump-celebrity-apprentice-host]] Trump is still credited as an executive producer for the show. [[CITE|525|https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/donald-trump-mark-burnett-celebrity-apprentice-executive-producer-1201937420]]

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Turnberry_Hotel|Turnberry Hotel]] and golf course, Ayrshire, Scotland

items.text: Professional wrestling

Trump is a [[LINK|lang_en|WWE|World Wrestling Entertainment]] fan and a friend of WWE chairman [[LINK|lang_en|Vince_McMahon|Vince McMahon]]. In 1988–89 Trump hosted [[LINK|lang_en|WrestleMania_IV|WrestleMania IV]] and [[LINK|lang_en|WrestleMania_V|V]] at [[LINK|lang_en|Boardwalk_Hall|Boardwalk Hall]] (dubbed "Trump Plaza" for storyline purposes) and has been an active participant in several of the shows. [[CITE|1073|http://wwe.com/superstars/donald-trump]] He also appeared in [[LINK|lang_en|WrestleMania_VII|WrestleMania VII]], and was interviewed ringside at [[LINK|lang_en|WrestleMania_XX|WrestleMania XX]], in 1991 and 2004, respectively. [[CITE|314|http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/Wrestlemania20/2004/03/15/382633.html]] Trump appeared at 2007's [[LINK|lang_en|WrestleMania_23|WrestleMania 23]] in a match called "The Battle of the Billionaires". [[CITE|1073|http://wwe.com/superstars/donald-trump]] He was in [[LINK|lang_en|Bobby_Lashley|Bobby Lashley]]'s corner, while Vince McMahon was in the corner of Lashley's opponent [[LINK|lang_en|Umaga_(wrestler)|Umaga]], with [[LINK|lang_en|Stone_Cold_Steve_Austin|Stone Cold Steve Austin]] as the special guest referee. [[CITE|1073|http://wwe.com/superstars/donald-trump]] The terms of the match were that either Trump or McMahon would have their head shaved if their competitor lost. [[CITE|1073|http://wwe.com/superstars/donald-trump]] Lashley won the match, and so McMahon was shaved bald. [[CITE|1073|http://wwe.com/superstars/donald-trump]] On June 15, 2009, McMahon announced as [[LINK|lang_en|Kayfabe|part of a storyline]] on *[[LINK|lang_en|WWE_Raw|Monday Night Raw]] * that he had "sold" the show to Trump. [[CITE|1073|http://wwe.com/superstars/donald-trump]] Appearing on screen, Trump declared that he would be at the following commercial-free episode in person and would give a full refund to the people who purchased tickets to the arena for that night's show. [[CITE|1073|http://wwe.com/superstars/donald-trump]] McMahon "bought back"*Raw* the following week for twice the price. [[CITE|1073|http://wwe.com/superstars/donald-trump]] In 2013, Trump was inducted into the celebrity wing of the [[LINK|lang_en|WWE_Hall_of_Fame|WWE Hall of Fame]] at [[LINK|lang_en|Madison_Square_Garden|Madison Square Garden]] for his contributions to the promotion. He made his sixth WrestleMania appearance the following night at [[LINK|lang_en|WrestleMania_29|WrestleMania 29]]. [[CITE|389|http://wwe.com/classics/wwe-hall-of-fame/donald-trump-announced-for-wwe-hall-of-fame-26090724]]

As president, Trump appointed WWE CEO [[LINK|lang_en|Linda_McMahon|Linda McMahon]] to his Cabinet as [[LINK|lang_en|Administrator_of_the_Small_Business_Administration|Administrator of the Small Business Administration]].
Acting and public image

Trump has made [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_filmography|cameo appearances]] in 12 films and 14 television series. [[CITE|121|http://worldcat.org/issn/0458-3035]] He played an oil tycoon in *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Little_Rascals_(film)|The Little Rascals]] *, and had a singing role at the [[LINK|lang_en|58th_Primetime_Emmy_Awards|58th Primetime Emmy Awards]] in 2006. [[CITE|121|http://worldcat.org/issn/0458-3035]] Trump is a member of the [[LINK|lang_en|Screen_Actors_Guild|Screen Actors Guild]] and receives an annual pension of more than $110,000. [[CITE|121|http://worldcat.org/issn/0458-3035]] [[CITE|121|http://worldcat.org/issn/0458-3035]] His television reality show *The Apprentice* was twice (2004 and 2005) nominated for an [[LINK|lang_en|Emmy_Award|Emmy Award]]. [[CITE|121|http://worldcat.org/issn/0458-3035]]

Trump has been the subject of comedians, [[LINK|lang_en|Flash_animation|flash cartoon]] artists, and online caricature artists. He has been parodied regularly on [[LINK|lang_en|Saturday_Night_Live_parodies_of_Donald_Trump|Saturday Night Live]] by [[LINK|lang_en|Phil_Hartman|Phil Hartman]], [[LINK|lang_en|Darrell_Hammond|Darrell Hammond]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Alec_Baldwin|Alec Baldwin]], and in *[[LINK|lang_en|South_Park|South Park]] * as [[LINK|lang_en|Mr._Garrison|Mr. Garrison]]. *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Simpsons|The Simpsons]] * episode "[[LINK|lang_en|Bart_to_the_Future|Bart to the Future]]", written during his [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_presidential_campaign,_2000|2000 campaign for the Reform party]], anticipated a future Trump presidency. A dedicated parody series called *[[LINK|lang_en|The_President_Show|The President Show]] * debuted in April 2017. [[CITE|121|http://worldcat.org/issn/0458-3035]]

Starting in the 1990s, Trump was a guest about 24 times on the nationally syndicated *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Howard_Stern_Show|Howard Stern Show]] * on talk radio. Trump also had his own daily [[LINK|lang_en|Talk_radio|talk radio]] program called *[[LINK|lang_en|Trumped!|Trumped!]] *, from 2004 to 2008. [[CITE|121|http://worldcat.org/issn/0458-3035]] [[CITE|600|http://trump.com/Donald_J_Trump/Biography.asp]] Since the 1980s, Trump's wealth and lifestyle have been a fixture of [[LINK|lang_en|Hip_hop|hip hop]] lyrics, [[CITE|59|http://awm.com/donald-trump-lyrics]] his name being quoted by more than 50 artists. [[CITE|159|https://youtube.com/watch?v=m3PDW6g1ceU]]
Political career up to 2015
Early involvement in politics
Trump first vaguely expressed interest in running for office in 1987, when he spent almost $100,000 to place full-page advertisements in several newspapers.

In his view at that time, "America should stop paying to defend countries that can afford to defend themselves", and "should present Western Europe and Japan with a bill for America's efforts to safeguard the passage of oil tankers in the Persian Gulf."

[[CITE|1003|https://washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1987/09/02/between-the-lines-of-a-millionaires-ad/9c6db9c3-f7d6-4aa4-9ec4-a312feb2639e]] According to a [[LINK|lang_en|Gallup_(company)|Gallup]] poll in December 1988, Trump was the tenth most admired person in America.

Trump considered running for president in [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_presidential_primaries,_1988|1988]],, [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_presidential_primaries,_2004|2004]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_presidential_primaries,_2012|2012]], and for [[LINK|lang_en|Governor_of_New_York|Governor of New York]] in 2006 and 2014, but aside from 2000 did not enter any of those races. [[CITE|477|http://nypost.com/2015/05/30/stop-pretending-donald-trump-is-not-running-for-president]] [[CITE|560|http://cnn.com/2011/POLITICS/05/16/trump.again]] In February 2009, Trump appeared on the *[[LINK|lang_en|Late_Show_with_David_Letterman|Late Show with David Letterman]] *, and spoke about the [[LINK|lang_en|Automotive_industry_crisis_of_2008–10|automotive industry crisis of 2008–10]]. He said that "instead of asking for money", [[LINK|lang_en|General_Motors|General Motors]]"should go into bankruptcy and work that stuff out in a deal." [[CITE|916|http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/02/19/trump-gm-should-file-for-bankruptcy]]

Trump publicly speculated about seeking the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election,_2012|2012]] Republican presidential nomination, and a *Wall Street Journal* / NBC News poll released in March 2011 found Trump leading among potential contenders; he was one point ahead of former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney. [[CITE|1035|http://nbcnewyork.com/news/politics/Trump_tops_Romney__Pawlenty-117496043.html]] A *Newsweek* poll conducted in February 2011 showed Trump within a few points of incumbent president Barack Obama, with many voters undecided in the November 2012 general election for president of the United States. [[CITE|1057|http://thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-02-21/obama-hits-50-percent-approval-rating-according-to-new-newsweekdaily-beast-poll]] A poll released in April 2011 by [[LINK|lang_en|Public_Policy_Polling|Public Policy Polling]] showed Trump having a nine-point lead in a potential contest for the Republican nomination for president while he was still actively considering a run. [[CITE|902|http://nydailynews.com/news/politics/donald-trump-takes-lead-gop-primary-poll-beats-romney-huckabee-palin-gingrich-bachmann-paul-article-1.112460]] [[CITE|51|http://publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/PPP_Release_US_0510925.pdf]] His moves were interpreted by some media as possible promotional tools for his reality show *The Apprentice*. [[CITE|87|http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2011/05/16/breaking-trump-not-running-for-president?hpt=T2]] [[CITE|171|http://csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/The-Vote/2011/0210/Donald-Trump-says-he-might-run-for-president.-Three-reasons-he-won-t]] [[CITE|201|http://huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/11/donald-trump-cpac-president-act_n_821923.html]]

Trump played a leading role in [[LINK|lang_en|Barack_Obama_citizenship_conspiracy_theories|"birther" conspiracy theories]] that had been circulating since President [[LINK|lang_en|Barack_Obama|Obama's]] 2008 presidential campaign. [[CITE|298|http://cnn.com/2016/09/15/politics/donald-trump-obama-birther-united-states]] [[CITE|405|http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-perpetuated-birther-movement-years/story?id=42138176]] Beginning in March 2011, Trump publicly questioned Obama's citizenship and eligibility to serve as president. [[CITE|490|https://nytimes.com/2016/07/03/us/politics/donald-trump-birther-obama.html]] [[CITE|778|https://nytimes.com/2016/09/17/us/politics/donald-trump-birther-obama.html]] [[CITE|1081|http://factcheck.org/2016/09/trump-surrogates-spin-birther-narrative]] Although the Obama campaign had released a copy of the short-form birth certificate in 2008, [[CITE|682|http://ac360.blogs.cnn.com/2011/04/25/trump-claims-obama-birth-certificate-missing]] Trump demanded to see the original "long-form" certificate. [[CITE|490|https://nytimes.com/2016/07/03/us/politics/donald-trump-birther-obama.html]] He mentioned having sent investigators to Hawaii to research the question, but he did not follow up with any findings. [[CITE|490|https://nytimes.com/2016/07/03/us/politics/donald-trump-birther-obama.html]] He also repeated a debunked allegation that Obama's grandmother said she had witnessed his birth in Kenya. [[CITE|335|http://politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2011/apr/07/donald-trump/donald-trump-says-president-obamas-grandmother-cau]] [[CITE|570|http://cdn.factcheck.org/UploadedFiles/2011/04/bergtranscriptofmcreacall.pdf]] When the [[LINK|lang_en|White_House|White House]] later released Obama's long-form birth certificate, [[CITE|281|https://nytimes.com/2011/04/28/us/politics/28obama.html]] Trump took credit for obtaining the document, saying "I hope it checks out." [[CITE|823|http://cbsnews.com/news/trump-takes-credit-for-obama-birth-certificate-release-but-wonders-is-it-real]] His official biography mentions his purported role in forcing Obama's hand, [[CITE|423|http://trump.com/biography]] and he has defended his pursuit of the issue when prompted, later saying that his promotion of the conspiracy made him "very popular". [[CITE|478|http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trumps-history-raising-birther-questions-president-obama/story?id=33861832]] In 2011, Trump had called for Obama to release his student records, questioning whether his grades warranted entry into an [[LINK|lang_en|Ivy_League|Ivy League]] school. [[CITE|610|http://cbsnews.com/news/trump-how-did-obama-get-into-the-ivy-league]] When asked in 2015 whether he believed Obama was born in the United States, Trump said he did not want to discuss the matter further. [[CITE|854|http://cnn.com/2015/07/08/politics/donald-trump-illegal-immigrant-workers]] [[CITE|564|https://usatoday.com/story/life/2017/09/12/eric-and-lara-trump-announce-birth-son-potus-ninth-grandchild/658130001]] In September 2016, Trump publicly acknowledged that Obama was born in the U.S., and said that the rumors had been started by [[LINK|lang_en|Hillary_Clinton|Hillary Clinton]] during her [[LINK|lang_en|Hillary_Clinton_presidential_campaign,_2008|2008 presidential campaign]]. [[CITE|778|https://nytimes.com/2016/09/17/us/politics/donald-trump-birther-obama.html]] [[CITE|564|https://usatoday.com/story/life/2017/09/12/eric-and-lara-trump-announce-birth-son-potus-ninth-grandchild/658130001]] [[CITE|564|https://usatoday.com/story/life/2017/09/12/eric-and-lara-trump-announce-birth-son-potus-ninth-grandchild/658130001]]

Trump made his first speaking appearance at the [[LINK|lang_en|Conservative_Political_Action_Conference|Conservative Political Action Conference]] (CPAC) in February 2011. His appearance at CPAC was organized by [[LINK|lang_en|GOProud|GOProud]], an [[LINK|lang_en|LGBT_conservatism|LGBT conservative]] organization, in conjunction with GOProud supporter [[LINK|lang_en|Roger_Stone|Roger Stone]], who was close with Trump. GOProud pushed for a write-in campaign for Trump at CPAC's presidential straw poll. The 2011 CPAC speech Trump gave is credited for helping kick-start his political career within the [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_(United_States)|Republican Party]]. [[CITE|564|https://usatoday.com/story/life/2017/09/12/eric-and-lara-trump-announce-birth-son-potus-ninth-grandchild/658130001]] [[CITE|564|https://usatoday.com/story/life/2017/09/12/eric-and-lara-trump-announce-birth-son-potus-ninth-grandchild/658130001]]

In the [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_presidential_primaries,_2012|2012 Republican primaries]], Trump generally had polled at or below 17 percent among the crowded field of possible candidates. [[CITE|948|http://publicpolicypolling.blogspot.com/2011/05/trump-collapses.html]] On May 16, 2011, Trump announced he would not run for president in the 2012 election, while also saying he would have become the President of the United States, had he run. [[CITE|87|http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2011/05/16/breaking-trump-not-running-for-president?hpt=T2]]
In 2013, Trump was a featured speaker at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC).
