During the lightly attended early-morning speech, Trump spoke out against illegal immigration, then-President Obama's "unprecedented media protection", and advised against harming Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security.

[[CITE|564|https://usatoday.com/story/life/2017/09/12/eric-and-lara-trump-announce-birth-son-potus-ninth-grandchild/658130001]] [[CITE|564|https://usatoday.com/story/life/2017/09/12/eric-and-lara-trump-announce-birth-son-potus-ninth-grandchild/658130001]]
Additionally, Trump spent over $1 million in 2013 to research a possible run for president of the United States.

[[CITE|479|http://pagesix.com/2013/05/27/trump-researching-2016-run]] In October 2013, New York Republicans circulated a memo suggesting Trump should run for governor of the state in 2014 against [[LINK|lang_en|Andrew_Cuomo|Andrew Cuomo]]. In response to the memo, Trump said that while New York had problems and that its taxes were too high, running for governor was not of great interest to him. [[CITE|919|http://foxnews.com/politics/2016/03/27/trumps-daughter-ivanka-gives-birth-to-third-child.html]] In January 2014, Trump made statements [[LINK|lang_en|Climate_change_denial|denying climate change]] that were discordant with the [[LINK|lang_en|Scientific_opinion_on_climate_change|opinion of the scientific community]]. [[CITE|919|http://foxnews.com/politics/2016/03/27/trumps-daughter-ivanka-gives-birth-to-third-child.html]] A February 2014 Quinnipiac poll had shown Trump losing to the more popular Cuomo by 37 points in a hypothetical election. [[CITE|919|http://foxnews.com/politics/2016/03/27/trumps-daughter-ivanka-gives-birth-to-third-child.html]] In February 2015, Trump told NBC that he was not prepared to sign on for another season of *The Apprentice*, as he mulled his political future.
Political affiliations
Trump's political party affiliation has changed numerous times over the years.
Trump was a Democrat prior to 1987.

[[CITE|845|http://archive.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/blogs/hilary-sargent/2014/01/22/the-man-responsible-for-donald-trump-never-ending-presidential-campaign/95LunCt63n3xKoq5DyJNFI/blog.html]] In 1987, Trump registered as a Republican in Manhattan.
[[CITE|242|http://politifact.com/florida/statements/2015/aug/24/jeb-bush/bush-says-trump-was-democrat-longer-republican-las]]

In 1999, Trump switched to the Reform Party and ran a [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_presidential_campaign,_2000|presidential exploratory campaign]] for its nomination. After his run, Trump left the party in 2001 due to the involvement of [[LINK|lang_en|David_Duke|David Duke]], [[LINK|lang_en|Pat_Buchanan|Pat Buchanan]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Lenora_Fulani|Lenora Fulani]].

From 2001 to 2008, Trump identified himself as a Democrat, but in 2008, he endorsed Republican [[LINK|lang_en|John_McCain|John McCain]] for president. In 2009, he officially changed his party registration to Republican. [[CITE|919|http://foxnews.com/politics/2016/03/27/trumps-daughter-ivanka-gives-birth-to-third-child.html]] In December 2011, Trump became an independent for five months before returning to the Republican Party, where he later pledged to stay. [[CITE|919|http://foxnews.com/politics/2016/03/27/trumps-daughter-ivanka-gives-birth-to-third-child.html]] [[CITE|93|http://thesmokinggun.com/buster/donald-trump/donald-trump-voter-history-567920]]

Trump has made contributions to campaigns of both Republican Party and Democratic Party candidates, with the top ten recipients of his political contributions being six Democrats and four Republicans.
[[CITE|182|http://opensecrets.org/news/2011/02/donald-trumps-donations-to-democrats.html]] After 2011, his campaign contributions were more favorable to Republicans than to Democrats.

[[CITE|230|http://politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2015/jul/09/ben-fergurson/donald-trumps-campaign-contributions-democrats-and]] In February 2012, Trump openly endorsed Republican [[LINK|lang_en|Mitt_Romney|Mitt Romney]] for president. [[CITE|395|http://foxnews.com/politics/2012/02/02/trump-plans-to-endorse-romney-sources-say.html#]] When asked in 2015 which of the last four presidents he prefers, Trump picked Democrat [[LINK|lang_en|Bill_Clinton|Bill Clinton]] over the Republican [[LINK|lang_en|Bush_family#President|Bushes]]. [[CITE|315|http://politico.com/story/2015/06/donald-trump-bill-clinton-favorite-president-119114]] [[CITE|383|http://msnbc.com/morning-joe/watch/trump-weighs-in-on-best-president-466103363535]]

According to a New York state report, Trump circumvented corporate and personal campaign donation limits in the 1980s—although no laws were broken—by donating money to candidates from 18 different business subsidiaries, rather than donating primarily in his own name.
[[CITE|976|https://books.google.com/books?id=2msVCgAAQBAJ]] Trump told investigators he did so on the advice of his lawyers.
He also said the contributions were not to gain favor with business-friendly candidates, but simply to satisfy requests from friends.
[[CITE|297|http://ir.lawnet.fordham.edu/ulj/vol18/iss2/3]]
2000 presidential campaign

In 1999, Trump filed an [[LINK|lang_en|Exploratory_committee|exploratory committee]] to seek the presidential nomination of the [[LINK|lang_en|Reform_Party_of_the_United_States_of_America|Reform Party]] in 2000. [[CITE|661|http://ballot-access.org/2011/12/25/donald-trump-ran-for-president-in-2000-in-several-reform-party-presidential-primaries]] A July 1999 poll matching him against likely Republican nominee [[LINK|lang_en|George_W._Bush|George W. Bush]] and likely Democratic nominee [[LINK|lang_en|Al_Gore|Al Gore]] showed Trump with seven percent support. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Trump eventually dropped out of the race due to party infighting, but still went on to win the party's California and Michigan primaries. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]
2016 presidential campaign

On June 16, 2015, Trump announced his candidacy for President of the United States at [[LINK|lang_en|Trump_Tower|Trump Tower]] in Manhattan. In the speech, Trump drew attention to domestic issues such as [[LINK|lang_en|Illegal_immigration_to_the_United_States|illegal immigration]], [[LINK|lang_en|Offshoring|offshoring]] of American jobs, the [[LINK|lang_en|National_debt_of_the_United_States|U.S. national debt]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Islamic_terrorism|Islamic terrorism]], which all remained large priorities during the campaign. He also announced his campaign slogan, "[[LINK|lang_en|Make_America_Great_Again|Make America Great Again]]". [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

In his campaign, Trump said that he disdained [[LINK|lang_en|Political_correctness|political correctness]]; he also stated that the media had intentionally misinterpreted his words, and he made other claims of adverse [[LINK|lang_en|Media_bias|media bias]]. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] In part due to his fame, Trump received an unprecedented amount of [[LINK|lang_en|Earned_media|free media coverage]] during his run for the presidency, which elevated his standing in the Republican primaries. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

Republican leaders such as [[LINK|lang_en|Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives|House Speaker]] [[LINK|lang_en|Paul_Ryan|Paul Ryan]] were hesitant to support him during his early quest for the presidency. They doubted his chances of winning the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election,_2016|general election]] and feared that he could harm the image of the Republican Party. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|Alt-right|alt-right]] movement coalesced around Trump's candidacy, [[CITE|829|https://washingtonpost.com/news/the-intersect/wp/2016/06/03/anti-semitic-trump-supporters-made-a-giant-list-of-people-to-target-with-a-racist-meme]] due in part to its [[LINK|lang_en|Criticism_of_multiculturalism|opposition to multiculturalism]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Opposition_to_immigration|immigration]]. [[CITE|1106|http://cnn.com/2016/08/25/politics/alt-right-explained-hillary-clinton-donald-trump]] [[CITE|254|http://ft.com/cms/s/0/e148d930-6cdb-11e6-9ac1-1055824ca907.html]] The connection of this group to the Trump campaign is controversial; writers such as [[LINK|lang_en|Jon_Ronson|Jon Ronson]] have suggested that the link between Trump and right-wing figures such as [[LINK|lang_en|Alex_Jones_(radio_host)|Alex Jones]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Roger_Stone|Roger Stone]] is a [[LINK|lang_en|Marriage_of_convenience|marriage of convenience]]. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Trump personally condemned the alt-right in an interview after the election. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

During the campaign, Trump was accused of pandering to [[LINK|lang_en|White_nationalist|white nationalists]], [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] especially in his initial refusal to condemn the support of [[LINK|lang_en|David_Duke|David Duke]] —a former [[LINK|lang_en|Grand_Wizard|Imperial Wizard]] of the [[LINK|lang_en|Ku_Klux_Klan|Ku Klux Klan]] —in a CNN interview with [[LINK|lang_en|Jake_Tapper|Jake Tapper]]. He had previously criticized Duke in 1991, disavowed the 2000 Reform Party due to the support of Duke and others, and disavowed Duke on the campaign trail both before and after the interview. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] In August, he appointed [[LINK|lang_en|Steve_Bannon|Steve Bannon]] —the executive chairman of [[LINK|lang_en|Breitbart_News|Breitbart News]] —as his campaign CEO; the website was described by Bannon as "the platform for the alt-right." [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] However, Bannon later told the *[[LINK|lang_en|Wall_Street_Journal|Wall Street Journal]] * that he was an "economic nationalist" but not "a supporter of [[LINK|lang_en|Ethno-nationalism|ethno-nationalism]]." [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] According to [[LINK|lang_en|Michael_Barkun|Michael Barkun]], the Trump campaign was remarkable for bringing fringe ideas, beliefs, and organizations into the mainstream. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]
Some rallies during the primary season were accompanied by protests or violence, including attacks on Trump supporters and vice-versa both inside and outside the venues.

[[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

caption.text: Trump posing with former NBA basketball player [[LINK|lang_en|Dennis_Rodman|Dennis Rodman]] during Rodman's 2009 participation on *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Apprentice_(U.S._TV_series)|Celebrity Apprentice]] *

items.text: Campaign rhetoric
Fact-checking organizations have denounced Trump for making a record number of false statements compared to other candidates.

[[CITE|188|http://factcheck.org/2015/12/the-king-of-whoppers-donald-trump]] [[CITE|406|http://politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2015/dec/21/2015-lie-year-donald-trump-campaign-misstatements]] [[CITE|635|https://washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/the-existential-crisis-of-professional-factcheckers-in-the-year-of-trump/2016/02/25/e994f210-db3e-11e5-81ae-7491b9b9e7df_story.html]] At least four major publications – *Politico*, *The Washington Post*, *The New York Times*, and the *Los Angeles Times* – have pointed out lies or falsehoods in his campaign statements. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] *[[LINK|lang_en|NPR|NPR]] * said that Trump's campaign statements were often opaque or suggestive. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Lucas Graves, an assistant professor of journalism and mass communication at the [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_Wisconsin–Madison|University of Wisconsin–Madison]], [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] opined that Trump "often speaks in a suggestive way that makes it unclear what exactly he meant, so that fact-checkers "have to be really careful" when picking claims to check, "to pick things that reflect what the speaker was clearly trying to communicate." [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

Trump's penchant for [[LINK|lang_en|Hyperbole|hyperbole]] is believed to have roots in the New York real estate scene, where Trump established his wealth and where [[LINK|lang_en|Puffery|puffery]] abounds. [[CITE|450|https://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-hyperbole-insight-idUSKCN0QX11X20150828]] Trump has called his public speaking style "truthful hyperbole", an effective political tactic that may, however, backfire for overpromising. [[CITE|450|https://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-hyperbole-insight-idUSKCN0QX11X20150828]] Martin Medhurst, a [[LINK|lang_en|Baylor_University|Baylor University]] professor of communication and political science, analyzed Trump's frequently used [[LINK|lang_en|Rhetorical_devices|rhetorical devices]], such as catchy slogans, hyperbole, insinuations and [[LINK|lang_en|Preterition|preterition]]. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]
Financial disclosures

In compliance with [[LINK|lang_en|Federal_Election_Commission|FEC]] regulations of all presidential candidates, Trump published a 92-page financial disclosure form in 2015; the form listed all of his assets, liabilities, income sources and hundreds of business positions. [[CITE|181|https://washingtonpost.com/wp-stat/graphics/politics/trump-archive/docs/trump-fec-financial-disclosure-2015.pdf]] His decision not to release his tax returns [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] was contrary to usual practice by every presidential candidate since [[LINK|lang_en|Gerald_Ford|Gerald Ford]] in 1976. [[CITE|348|https://nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/05/11/donald-trump-breaks-with-recent-history-by-not-releasing-tax-returns?_r=0]] Although there is no law that requires presidential candidates to release their returns, [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Trump's refusal led to speculation that he was hiding something. [[CITE|239|http://cnn.com/2016/02/24/politics/mitt-romney-donald-trump-taxes]] Trump explained that his tax returns were being audited and his lawyers had advised him against releasing the returns. [[CITE|283|http://money.cnn.com/2016/02/26/pf/taxes/trump-tax-returns-audit]] However, no law prohibits release of tax returns during an audit. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Tax attorneys differ about whether such a release is wise legal strategy. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Trump has told the news media that his tax rate was "none of your business", but added, "I fight very hard to pay as little tax as possible." [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|751|http://politico.com/story/2016/01/donald-trump-tax-returns-218160]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

On October 1, 2016, three pages of Trump's 1995 tax return were leaked to a reporter from *[[LINK|lang_en|The_New_York_Times|The New York Times]] *, who said she received the documents in her *Times* mailbox. Each of the three pages is one page from Trump's state filings in Connecticut, New York, and New Jersey. They show that using allowed deductions for losses, Trump claimed a loss of $916 million that year. During the second presidential debate, Trump acknowledged using the deduction, but declined to provide details such as the specific years it was applied. [[CITE|501|https://nytimes.com/2016/10/10/us/politics/donald-trump-taxes.html]] When asked if he used the tax code to avoid paying taxes, he said, "Of course I did. Of course I did." He then went on to say he paid "hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes", calling it a "simple" thing. "I pay tax, and I pay federal tax, too", he said. [[CITE|753|http://politico.com/story/2016/10/2016-presidential-debate-transcript-229519]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

On March 14, 2017, the first two pages of Trump's 2005 federal income tax returns were leaked to [[LINK|lang_en|MSNBC|MSNBC]]'s [[LINK|lang_en|Rachel_Maddow|Rachel Maddow]], who unveiled them on [[LINK|lang_en|The_Rachel_Maddow_Show|her show]]. The two pages showed that Trump paid $38 million in federal taxes and had a gross adjusted income of $150 million. [[CITE|491|https://nytimes.com/2017/03/14/us/politics/donald-trump-taxes.html]] [[CITE|55|http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/324016-wh-releases-trump-tax-info-ahead-of-msnbc-report-made-150m-in-2005]] The White House confirmed the authenticity of the 2005 documents and stated: "Despite this substantial income figure and tax paid, it is totally illegal to steal and publish tax returns." [[CITE|491|https://nytimes.com/2017/03/14/us/politics/donald-trump-taxes.html]] [[CITE|55|http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/324016-wh-releases-trump-tax-info-ahead-of-msnbc-report-made-150m-in-2005]]
Republican primaries
Trump entered a field of 17 major candidates who were vying for the 2016 Republican nomination; this was the largest presidential field in American history.

[[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Trump participated in eleven of the twelve [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_presidential_debates_and_forums,_2016|Republican debates]], skipping only the January 28 seventh debate, which was the last debate before primary voting began on the first of February. The debates received historically high television ratings, which increased the visibility of Trump's campaign. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

By early 2016, the race had mostly centered on Trump and [[LINK|lang_en|U.S._Senator|U.S. Senator]] [[LINK|lang_en|Ted_Cruz|Ted Cruz]]. [[CITE|683|http://fortune.com/2016/03/06/cruz-trump-republican-race]] On [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_presidential_primaries,_2016#March_1,_2016:_Super_Tuesday|Super Tuesday]], Trump won the plurality of the vote, and he remained the front-runner throughout the remainder of the primaries. By March 2016, Trump became poised to win the Republican nomination. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] After a landslide win in [[LINK|lang_en|Indiana_Republican_primary,_2016|Indiana]] on May 3, 2016—which prompted the remaining candidates Ted Cruz and [[LINK|lang_en|John_Kasich|John Kasich]] to suspend their presidential campaigns— [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_National_Committee|RNC]] Chairman [[LINK|lang_en|Reince_Priebus|Reince Priebus]] declared Trump the presumptive Republican nominee. [[CITE|717|http://politico.com/blogs/2016-gop-primary-live-updates-and-results/2016/05/reince-priebus-donald-trump-is-nominee-222767]] With nearly 14 million votes, Trump broke the all-time record in the history of the Republican Party for winning the most primary votes. He also set the record for the largest number of votes cast against the front runner. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

caption.text: Trump's September 1987 advertisement in *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Boston_Globe|The Boston Globe]] *, criticizing U.S. defense policy

items.text: General election campaign

After becoming the presumptive Republican nominee, Trump shifted his focus to the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election,_2016|general election]]. He urged remaining primary voters to "save [their] vote for the general election." [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Trump began campaigning against [[LINK|lang_en|Hillary_Clinton|Hillary Clinton]], who became the presumptive [[LINK|lang_en|Democratic_Party_(United_States)|Democratic]] nominee on June 6, 2016, and continued to campaign across the country.

Clinton had established a significant lead over Trump in [[LINK|lang_en|Nationwide_opinion_polling_for_the_United_States_presidential_election,_2016|national polls]] throughout most of 2016. In early July, Clinton's lead narrowed in national polling averages following the [[LINK|lang_en|FBI|FBI]]'s re-opening of its investigation into her ongoing [[LINK|lang_en|Hillary_Clinton_email_controversy|email controversy]]. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

On July 15, 2016, Trump announced his selection of [[LINK|lang_en|Indiana|Indiana]] [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Governor|Governor]] [[LINK|lang_en|Mike_Pence|Mike Pence]] as his [[LINK|lang_en|Running_mate|running mate]]. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Four days later on July 19, Trump and Pence were officially nominated by the Republican Party at the Republican National Convention. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] The list of convention speakers and attendees included former presidential nominee [[LINK|lang_en|Bob_Dole|Bob Dole]], but the other prior nominees did not attend. [[CITE|174|http://nbcnews.com/storyline/2016-conventions/9-elephants-room-rnc-what-s-missing-speakers-list-n609471]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

Two days later, Trump officially accepted the nomination in a 76-minute speech that was inspired by [[LINK|lang_en|Richard_Nixon|Richard Nixon]]'s 1968 acceptance speech. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] The historically long speech was watched by nearly 35 million people and received mixed reviews, with net negative viewer reactions according to CNN and Gallup polls. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

On September 26, 2016, Donald Trump and [[LINK|lang_en|Hillary_Clinton|Hillary Clinton]] faced off in [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election_debates,_2016#First_presidential_debate_(Hofstra_University)|their first presidential debate]], which was held at [[LINK|lang_en|Hofstra_University|Hofstra University]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Hempstead,_New_York|Hempstead, New York]]. [[LINK|lang_en|NBC_News|NBC News]] anchor [[LINK|lang_en|Lester_Holt|Lester Holt]] was the moderator. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] The TV broadcast was the most watched presidential debate in United States history. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] The [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election_debates,_2016#Second_presidential_debate_(Washington_University_in_St._Louis)|second presidential debate]] was held at [[LINK|lang_en|Washington_University_in_Saint_Louis|Washington University]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Saint_Louis,_Missouri|Saint Louis, Missouri]]. The beginning narrative of that debate was dominated by a [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_and_Billy_Bush_recording|leaked tape of Trump making lewd comments]], and counter-accusations by Trump of sexual misconduct done by [[LINK|lang_en|Bill_Clinton|Bill Clinton]]. Trump had invited four women who had accused Clinton of impropriety to a press conference prior to the debate. The [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election_debates,_2016#Third_presidential_debate_(University_of_Nevada,_Las_Vegas)|final presidential debate]] was held on October 19 at the [[LINK|lang_en|University_of_Nevada,_Las_Vegas|University of Nevada, Las Vegas]]. Trump's refusal to say whether he would accept the result of the election, regardless of the outcome, drew particular press attention. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

caption.text: Trump speaking at the [[LINK|lang_en|Conservative_Political_Action_Conference|Conservative Political Action Conference]] in 2011

items.text: Political positions

Trump's campaign platform emphasized renegotiating [[LINK|lang_en|U.S.–China_relations|U.S.–China relations]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Free_trade|free trade]] agreements such as [[LINK|lang_en|NAFTA|NAFTA]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Trans-Pacific_Partnership|Trans-Pacific Partnership]], strongly enforcing [[LINK|lang_en|Illegal_immigration_to_the_United_States|immigration laws]], and building [[LINK|lang_en|Mexico–United_States_barrier|a new wall]] along the [[LINK|lang_en|U.S.–Mexico_border|U.S.–Mexico border]]. His other campaign positions included pursuing [[LINK|lang_en|Energy_independence|energy independence]] while opposing [[LINK|lang_en|Climate_change|climate change]] regulations such as the [[LINK|lang_en|Clean_Power_Plan|Clean Power Plan]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Paris_Agreement|Paris Agreement]], modernizing and expediting [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Department_of_Veterans_Affairs|services for veterans]], repealing and replacing the [[LINK|lang_en|Affordable_Care_Act|Affordable Care Act]], abolishing [[LINK|lang_en|Common_Core|Common Core]] education standards, [[LINK|lang_en|Infrastructure-based_development|investing in infrastructure]], simplifying the [[LINK|lang_en|Internal_Revenue_Code|tax code]] while reducing taxes for all economic classes, and imposing [[LINK|lang_en|Tariff|tariffs]] on imports by companies that [[LINK|lang_en|Offshoring|offshore]] jobs. During the campaign, he also advocated a largely [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_non-interventionism|non-interventionist]] approach to [[LINK|lang_en|Foreign_policy_of_the_United_States|foreign policy]] while increasing [[LINK|lang_en|Military_budget_of_the_United_States|military spending]], [[LINK|lang_en|Extreme_vetting|extreme vetting]] of immigrants from [[LINK|lang_en|Muslim-majority_countries|Muslim-majority countries]] to pre-empt domestic [[LINK|lang_en|Islamic_terrorism|Islamic terrorism]], and aggressive military action against [[LINK|lang_en|Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant|Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL, also known as ISIS or IS).

Media have described Trump's political positions as "[[LINK|lang_en|Populism|populist]]", [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] and some of his views cross party lines. For example, his economic campaign plan calls for large reductions in [[LINK|lang_en|Corporate_tax_in_the_United_States#Tax_rates|income taxes]] and deregulation, [[CITE|107|https://donaldjtrump.com/positions/tax-reform]] consistent with Republican Party policies, along with significant infrastructure investment, [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] usually considered a liberal (Democratic Party) policy. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] According to political writer [[LINK|lang_en|Jack_Shafer|Jack Shafer]], Trump may be a "fairly conventional American populist when it comes to his policy views", but he attracts [[LINK|lang_en|Earned_media|free media attention]], sometimes by making outrageous comments. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]
Trump has supported or leaned toward varying political positions over time.

[[CITE|452|https://washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2015/08/17/20-times-donald-trump-has-changed-his-mind-since-june]] [[CITE|554|http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/247643-meet-the-press-tracks-trumps-flip-flops]] [[CITE|591|http://politico.com/story/2015/07/will-the-real-donald-trump-please-stand-up-120607]] *[[LINK|lang_en|Politico|Politico]] * has described his positions as "eclectic, improvisational and often contradictory", [[CITE|591|http://politico.com/story/2015/07/will-the-real-donald-trump-please-stand-up-120607]] while [[LINK|lang_en|NBC_News|NBC News]] counted "141 distinct shifts on 23 major issues" during his campaign. [[CITE|954|http://nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/full-list-donald-trump-s-rapidly-changing-policy-positions-n547801]]
Russian interference in election

In January 2017, American intelligence agencies – the [[LINK|lang_en|Central_Intelligence_Agency|CIA]], [[LINK|lang_en|Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation|FBI]] and [[LINK|lang_en|National_Security_Agency|NSA]], represented by the [[LINK|lang_en|Director_of_National_Intelligence|Director of National Intelligence]] – jointly stated with "[[LINK|lang_en|Analytic_confidence#Levels_of_analytic_confidence_in_national_security_reports|high confidence]]" that the Russian government [[LINK|lang_en|Russian_interference_in_the_2016_United_States_elections|attempted to intervene]] in the 2016 presidential election to favor the election of Trump. [[CITE|160|https://dni.gov/files/documents/ICA_2017_01.pdf]] [[CITE|379|https://nytimes.com/interactive/2017/01/06/us/politics/document-russia-hacking-report-intelligence-agencies.html]] In testimony to the Senate Intelligence Committee on June 8, former FBI Director James Comey affirmed he has "no doubt" that Russia interfered in the 2016 election, adding "they did it with purpose and sophistication". [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|920|http://politi.co/2rae37O]]

Trump claims that the investigation of Russian interference in the U.S. election is the pursuit of a false narrative, calling it "the single greatest witch hunt of a politician in American history!"[[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Russian president [[LINK|lang_en|Vladimir_Putin|Vladimir Putin]] echoed Trump's opinion, saying that Democrats cling to this fictitious explanation to avoid confronting their election loss. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]
Interactions with Russia
There has been intensive media scrutiny of Trump's relationship to Russia.

[[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] During the campaign, Trump repeatedly praised Russian president Vladimir Putin as a strong leader. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] One of his campaign managers, [[LINK|lang_en|Paul_Manafort|Paul Manafort]], had worked for several years to help pro-Russian politician [[LINK|lang_en|Viktor_Yanukovich|Viktor Yanukovich]] win the Ukrainian presidency. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Other Trump associates, including former National Security Advisor [[LINK|lang_en|Michael_T._Flynn|Michael T. Flynn]] and political consultant Roger Stone, have been connected to Russian officials. [[CITE|664|http://time.com/4433880/donald-trump-ties-to-russia]] [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]] Russian agents were overheard during the campaign saying they could use Manafort and Flynn to influence Trump. [[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]
Members of Trump's campaign and later his White House staff, particularly Flynn, were in contact with Russian officials both before and after the November election.

[[CITE|245|https://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-contacts-idUSKCN18E106]] In a December 29, 2016 conversation, Flynn and Kislyak discussed the recently imposed sanctions against Russia; Trump later fired Flynn for falsely claiming he had not discussed the sanctions.
[[CITE|418|http://cbc.ca/news/canada/trump-canada-yukon-1.3235254]]

In March 2017, [[LINK|lang_en|Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation|FBI Director]] [[LINK|lang_en|James_Comey|James Comey]] told Congress that "the FBI, as part of our counterintelligence mission, is investigating the Russian government's efforts to interfere in the 2016 presidential election. That includes investigating the nature of any links between individuals associated with the Trump campaign and the Russian government, and whether there was any coordination between the campaign and Russia's efforts." [[CITE|347|https://books.google.com/books?id=YEdwW78QWj0C&pg=PA251]]

In 2017, Trump and other senior White House officials asked the Director of National Intelligence, the NSA director, the FBI director, and two chairs of congressional committees to publicly dispute the news reports about contacts between Trump associates and Russia.
[[CITE|347|https://books.google.com/books?id=YEdwW78QWj0C&pg=PA251]]
Sexual misconduct allegations

Two days before the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election_debates,_2016#Second_presidential_debate_(Washington_University_in_St._Louis)|second presidential debate]], a [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_Access_Hollywood_controversy|2005 recording]] surfaced in which Trump was heard bragging about forcibly kissing and groping women. [[CITE|347|https://books.google.com/books?id=YEdwW78QWj0C&pg=PA251]] [[CITE|347|https://books.google.com/books?id=YEdwW78QWj0C&pg=PA251]] [[CITE|347|https://books.google.com/books?id=YEdwW78QWj0C&pg=PA251]] The [[LINK|lang_en|Microphone_gaffe|hot mic]] recording was captured on a studio bus in which Trump and [[LINK|lang_en|Billy_Bush|Billy Bush]] were preparing to film an episode of *[[LINK|lang_en|Access_Hollywood|Access Hollywood]].*"I just start kissing them," Trump said, "I don't even wait. And when you're a star, they let you do it, you can do anything... grab them by the pussy." [[CITE|41|https://washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-recorded-having-extremely-lewd-conversation-about-women-in-2005/2016/10/07/3b9ce776-8cb4-11e6-bf8a-3d26847eeed4_story.html]] During the recording, Trump also spoke of his efforts to seduce a married woman, saying he "moved on her very heavily." [[CITE|41|https://washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-recorded-having-extremely-lewd-conversation-about-women-in-2005/2016/10/07/3b9ce776-8cb4-11e6-bf8a-3d26847eeed4_story.html]] These statements were recorded several months after Trump married his third and current wife, Melania, who was pregnant at the time. [[CITE|41|https://washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-recorded-having-extremely-lewd-conversation-about-women-in-2005/2016/10/07/3b9ce776-8cb4-11e6-bf8a-3d26847eeed4_story.html]] [[CITE|347|https://books.google.com/books?id=YEdwW78QWj0C&pg=PA251]]

Trump's language on the tape was described by the media as "vulgar", "sexist", and descriptive of [[LINK|lang_en|Sexual_assault|sexual assault]]. The incident prompted him to make his first public apology during the campaign, [[CITE|347|https://books.google.com/books?id=YEdwW78QWj0C&pg=PA251]] [[CITE|347|https://books.google.com/books?id=YEdwW78QWj0C&pg=PA251]] and caused outrage across the political spectrum, [[CITE|347|https://books.google.com/books?id=YEdwW78QWj0C&pg=PA251]] [[CITE|426|http://cnn.com/2013/07/04/us/donald-trump-fast-facts]] with many Republicans withdrawing their endorsements of his candidacy and some urging him to quit the race. [[CITE|426|http://cnn.com/2013/07/04/us/donald-trump-fast-facts]] Subsequently, at least 15 women [[CITE|427|https://vox.com/2016/10/13/13269448/trump-sexual-assault-allegations]] came forward with new accusations of sexual misconduct, including unwanted kissing and groping, resulting in widespread media coverage. [[CITE|426|http://cnn.com/2013/07/04/us/donald-trump-fast-facts]] [[CITE|426|http://cnn.com/2013/07/04/us/donald-trump-fast-facts]]
Trump and his campaign have denied all of the sexual misconduct accusations, which Trump has called "false smears", and alleged a conspiracy against him.

[[CITE|426|http://cnn.com/2013/07/04/us/donald-trump-fast-facts]] [[CITE|161|http://foxnews.com/politics/2016/10/13/trump-demands-nyt-retracts-libelous-article-about-alleged-assault-as-new-claims-emerge.html]] [[CITE|426|http://cnn.com/2013/07/04/us/donald-trump-fast-facts]] In his two public statements in response to the controversy, [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump_and_Billy_Bush_recording#Trump_response|Trump responded]] by alleging that [[LINK|lang_en|Bill_Clinton|Bill Clinton]], former President of the United States and husband of Trump's Democratic rival [[LINK|lang_en|Hillary_Clinton|Hillary Clinton]], had "abused women" and that Hillary had bullied her husband's victims. [[CITE|426|http://cnn.com/2013/07/04/us/donald-trump-fast-facts]]
Election to the presidency

On Election Day, November 8, 2016, Trump received 306 [[LINK|lang_en|Electoral_College_(United_States)|electoral votes]] to Clinton's 232 votes. The counts were later adjusted to 304 and 227 respectively, after [[LINK|lang_en|Faithless_electors_in_the_United_States_presidential_election,_2016|defections on both sides]], formalizing Trump's election to the presidency. [[CITE|426|http://cnn.com/2013/07/04/us/donald-trump-fast-facts]] In the early hours of November 9, Clinton called Trump to concede the election. Trump then delivered his victory speech before hundreds of supporters in the [[LINK|lang_en|New_York_Hilton_Midtown|New York Hilton]] hotel. The speech was in contrast with some of his previous rhetoric, with Trump promising to heal the division caused by the election, thanking Clinton for her service to the country, and promising to be a president to all Americans. [[CITE|992|http://uk.businessinsider.com/trump-victory-speech-transcript-2016-11?IR=T&r=US]] [[CITE|56|https://yahoo.com/tv/donald-trump-makes-first-speech-080352428.html]]

Trump received a smaller share of the popular vote than Clinton, making him the fifth person to be elected president [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_elections_in_which_the_winner_lost_the_popular_vote|while losing the popular vote]]. [[CITE|234|http://pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/12/20/why-electoral-college-landslides-are-easier-to-win-than-popular-vote-ones]] Clinton finished ahead by 2.86 million votes or 2.1 percentage points, 48.04% to 46.09%, with neither candidate reaching a [[LINK|lang_en|Majority_rule|majority]] nationwide. [[CITE|894|http://ibtimes.com/popular-vote-update-why-hillary-clinton-didnt-win-majority-electorate-2447571]] [[CITE|1112|http://uselectionatlas.org/RESULTS/index.html]]

Trump's victory was considered a stunning political upset, as polls consistently showed Hillary Clinton leading nationwide (which were consistent with her win in the popular vote) and in most battleground states, while Trump's support had been underestimated throughout his campaign.

[[CITE|213|http://politico.com/story/2016/11/election-results-2016-clinton-trump-231070]] The errors in some state polls were later partially attributed to pollsters overestimating Clinton's support among well-educated and nonwhite voters, while underestimating Trump's support among white working-class voters.

[[CITE|384|https://nytimes.com/2016/11/10/upshot/why-trump-won-working-class-whites.html]] Trump won the perennial [[LINK|lang_en|Swing_state|swing states]] of [[LINK|lang_en|Florida|Florida]], [[LINK|lang_en|Iowa|Iowa]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Ohio|Ohio]], and flipped Clinton's "[[LINK|lang_en|Blue_wall_(politics)|blue wall]]" states of [[LINK|lang_en|Michigan|Michigan]], [[LINK|lang_en|Pennsylvania|Pennsylvania]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Wisconsin|Wisconsin]], which had been Democratic strongholds since the 1990s. Trump's victory marked the return of a Republican White House combined with [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Presidents_and_control_of_Congress|control of]] both chambers of [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Congress|Congress]], as was the case during parts of [[LINK|lang_en|George_W._Bush|George W. Bush]]'s presidency from [[LINK|lang_en|108th_United_States_Congress|2003]] to [[LINK|lang_en|109th_United_States_Congress|2007]].
Trump is the wealthiest president in U.S. history.
[[CITE|588|http://businessinsider.com/donald-trump-richest-us-president-in-history-2017-1]] He is also the first president without prior governmental or military experience.

[[CITE|754|http://theweek.com/speedreads/660840/donald-trump-first-president-no-government-military-experience]] [[CITE|995|https://usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/11/08/donald-trump-experience-president/93504134]] [[CITE|80|https://vox.com/policy-and-politics/2016/11/11/13587532/donald-trump-no-experience]] Of the 43 previous presidents, 38 had held prior elective office; two had not held elective office but had served in the Cabinet; and three had never held public office but had been commanding generals. [[CITE|80|https://vox.com/policy-and-politics/2016/11/11/13587532/donald-trump-no-experience]]

caption.text: Trump meets with President [[LINK|lang_en|Ronald_Reagan|Ronald Reagan]] at a 1987 White House reception.

items.text: Protests
Trump's election victory sparked protests across the United States.
His opponents took to the streets to amplify their opposition to Trump's views and denounce his inflammatory statements.
Trump initially said on Twitter that the protests consisted of "professional protesters, incited by the media", and were "unfair", but he later stated that he loves their passion for the country.

[[CITE|779|https://usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/11/10/trump-tweet-professional-protesters-media/93624612]] [[CITE|996|http://uk.businessinsider.com/trump-tweets-that-protesters-have-passion-for-our-great-country-2016-11?IR=T&r=US]] After Obama's re-election in 2012, Trump had tweeted "We can't let this happen. We should march on Washington and stop this travesty. Our nation is totally divided!"[[CITE|143|https://theverge.com/2016/11/11/13596932/trump-protestors-electoral-college-tweets]]

On the Saturday following Trump's inauguration, massive demonstrations took place in the United States and worldwide in protest of Trump; approximately 2,600,000 people took part in Women's Marches worldwide.

[[CITE|333|https://usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/21/womens-march-aims-start-movement-trump-inauguration/96864158]] One of these marches was the [[LINK|lang_en|Women's_March_on_Washington|Women's March on Washington]] (in Washington, D.C.), where over 500,000 people marched in opposition to Trump. [[CITE|1031|https://economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/03/family-affair]]
Electoral history

sentences.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_Party_presidential_primaries,_2016|Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016]]
[[LINK|lang_en|United_States_presidential_election,_2016|United States presidential election, 2016]]

items.text: Presidency
Transition

On November 10, Trump had his first ever meeting with outgoing president Barack Obama to discuss plans for an orderly [[LINK|lang_en|Presidential_transition_of_Donald_Trump|transition of power]]. *The New York Times* said, "It was an extraordinary show of cordiality and respect between two men who have been political enemies and are stylistic opposites." [[CITE|1031|https://economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/03/family-affair]] The BBC stated that "their antipathy was barely concealed" in "awkward photos" of the meeting. [[CITE|1031|https://economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/03/family-affair]]
White House appointments

New Jersey Governor [[LINK|lang_en|Chris_Christie|Chris Christie]] led Trump's transition team until November 11, 2016, when Vice President-elect Mike Pence took over. [[CITE|1031|https://economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/03/family-affair]]

In the White House, Trump chose [[LINK|lang_en|Republican_National_Committee|RNC]] chairman [[LINK|lang_en|Reince_Priebus|Reince Priebus]] as [[LINK|lang_en|White_House_Chief_of_Staff|White House Chief of Staff]]; [[CITE|1031|https://economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/03/family-affair]] he was replaced by retired Marine General [[LINK|lang_en|John_F._Kelly|John F. Kelly]] on July 28, 2017. [[CITE|692|https://web.archive.org/web/20170729021432/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/28/us/politics/reince-priebus-white-house-trump.html]] He appointed businessman and media executive [[LINK|lang_en|Steve_Bannon|Steve Bannon]] as [[LINK|lang_en|White_House_Chief_Strategist|White House Chief Strategist]]; [[CITE|1031|https://economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/03/family-affair]] Bannon resigned on August 18, 2017 and no replacement has been named. [[CITE|1031|https://economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/03/family-affair]]
Cabinet-level nominations

Trump's [[LINK|lang_en|Formation_of_Donald_Trump's_cabinet|cabinet nominations]] included Alabama Senator [[LINK|lang_en|Jeff_Sessions|Jeff Sessions]] as [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Attorney_General|Attorney General]], [[CITE|190|https://greatagain.gov/news/president-elect-donald-j-trump-selects-us-senator-jeff-sessions-attorney-general-lt-gen-michael.html]] financier [[LINK|lang_en|Steve_Mnuchin|Steve Mnuchin]] as [[LINK|lang_en|Secretary_of_the_Treasury|Secretary of the Treasury]], [[CITE|1031|https://economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/03/family-affair]] retired Marine Corps General [[LINK|lang_en|James_Mattis|James Mattis]] as [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Secretary_of_Defense|Secretary of Defense]], [[CITE|1117|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/21/us/politics/donald-trump-jared-kushner-justice-department.html]] and [[LINK|lang_en|ExxonMobil|ExxonMobil]] CEO [[LINK|lang_en|Rex_Tillerson|Rex Tillerson]] as [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Secretary_of_State|Secretary of State]]. [[CITE|1117|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/21/us/politics/donald-trump-jared-kushner-justice-department.html]] Trump also brought on board politicians who had opposed him during the presidential campaign, notably neurosurgeon [[LINK|lang_en|Ben_Carson|Ben Carson]] as [[LINK|lang_en|Secretary_of_Housing_and_Urban_Development|Secretary of Housing and Urban Development]], [[CITE|1117|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/21/us/politics/donald-trump-jared-kushner-justice-department.html]] and South Carolina Governor [[LINK|lang_en|Nikki_Haley|Nikki Haley]] as [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Ambassador_to_the_United_Nations|Ambassador to the United Nations]]. [[CITE|1117|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/21/us/politics/donald-trump-jared-kushner-justice-department.html]]

While most of Trump's nominees were approved by the GOP majority in the Senate, the confirmation of education reform activist [[LINK|lang_en|Betsy_DeVos|Betsy DeVos]] as [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Secretary_of_Education|Secretary of Education]] [[CITE|1117|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/21/us/politics/donald-trump-jared-kushner-justice-department.html]] required Vice President Pence to cast a rare [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_tie-breaking_votes_cast_by_vice_presidents_of_the_United_States|tie-breaking vote]]. [[CITE|1117|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/21/us/politics/donald-trump-jared-kushner-justice-department.html]]

Most cabinet members were unable to take office on [[LINK|lang_en|Inauguration_of_Donald_Trump|Inauguration Day]] because of delays in the formal [[LINK|lang_en|Cabinet_of_Donald_Trump#Confirmation_process_timeline|confirmation process]]. Part of the lateness was ascribed to delays in submitting background-check paperwork, and part to [[LINK|lang_en|Obstructionism|obstructionism]] by Senate Democrats. [[CITE|755|http://bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38913709]] The last Cabinet member, [[LINK|lang_en|Robert_Lighthizer|Robert Lighthizer]], took office as [[LINK|lang_en|U.S._Trade_Representative|U.S. Trade Representative]] on May 11, 2017, more than four months after his nomination. [[CITE|1117|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/21/us/politics/donald-trump-jared-kushner-justice-department.html]]
Pre-inauguration events

On November 22, Trump outlined his plan for [[LINK|lang_en|First_100_days_of_Donald_Trump's_presidency|his first 100 days in office]] in a video posted on YouTube. The plan included the United States' withdrawal from the [[LINK|lang_en|Trans-Pacific_Partnership|Trans-Pacific Partnership]] and asking the [[LINK|lang_en|U.S._Department_of_Defense|U.S. Department of Defense]] to develop a plan to protect the U.S. from [[LINK|lang_en|Cyber-attack|cyber-attack]]. [[CITE|1117|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/21/us/politics/donald-trump-jared-kushner-justice-department.html]] [[CITE|1117|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/21/us/politics/donald-trump-jared-kushner-justice-department.html]]

On December 7, *[[LINK|lang_en|Time_(magazine)|Time]] * named Trump as its "[[LINK|lang_en|Time_Person_of_the_Year|Person of the Year]]". [[CITE|442|http://time.com/time-person-of-the-year-2016-donald-trump-choice]] In an interview on *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Today_Show|The Today Show]] *, he said he was honored by the award, but he took issue with the magazine for referring to him as the "President of the Divided States of America." [[CITE|123|https://law360.com/articles/888127/3rd-circ-judge-trump-s-sister-stops-hearing-cases]] [[CITE|123|https://law360.com/articles/888127/3rd-circ-judge-trump-s-sister-stops-hearing-cases]] He also opposed *Time*' s decision to change its "Man of the Year" title to "Person of the Year" in 1999, describing the action as too "politically correct". [[CITE|123|https://law360.com/articles/888127/3rd-circ-judge-trump-s-sister-stops-hearing-cases]] On December 13 he was named *[[LINK|lang_en|Financial_Times|Financial Times]] * [[LINK|lang_en|Financial_Times_Person_of_the_Year|Person of the Year]]. [[CITE|162|https://msn.com/en-gb/news/video/person-of-the-year-donald-trump/vp-AAltx27]] In December 2016, *[[LINK|lang_en|Forbes|Forbes]] * ranked Trump the [[LINK|lang_en|Forbes_list_of_The_World's_Most_Powerful_People|second most powerful person in the world]], after [[LINK|lang_en|Vladimir_Putin|Vladimir Putin]] and before [[LINK|lang_en|Angela_Merkel|Angela Merkel]]. [[CITE|123|https://law360.com/articles/888127/3rd-circ-judge-trump-s-sister-stops-hearing-cases]]

Based on intelligence reports issued from October 2016 to January 2017, the Obama administration [[LINK|lang_en|Russian_interference_in_the_2016_United_States_elections|accused the Russian government of trying to influence the U.S. presidential election]] in favor of Trump, by supplying the [[LINK|lang_en|2016_Democratic_National_Committee_email_leak|DNC emails]] to [[LINK|lang_en|WikiLeaks|WikiLeaks]] for publication. [[CITE|613|https://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-cyber-idUSKBN1441RS]] Trump, [[CITE|123|https://law360.com/articles/888127/3rd-circ-judge-trump-s-sister-stops-hearing-cases]] WikiLeaks [[CITE|1075|http://politico.com/story/2016/11/julian-assange-russia-john-podesta-wikileaks-230676]] and Russian officials [[CITE|273|https://bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-12-15/russia-rejects-as-rubbish-claims-putin-directed-u-s-hacking]] have denied the allegations.
Early actions

[[LINK|lang_en|Inauguration_of_Donald_Trump|Trump's inauguration]] as the 45th president was held on Friday, January 20, 2017. In his first week as president, Trump signed six [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_executive_actions_by_Donald_Trump|executive orders]]. His [[LINK|lang_en|Executive_Order_13765|first order]] as president set out interim procedures in anticipation of repeal of the [[LINK|lang_en|Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act|Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] (Obamacare). That same week, Trump withdrew the United States from the [[LINK|lang_en|Trans-Pacific_Partnership|Trans-Pacific Partnership]], re-instated the [[LINK|lang_en|Mexico_City_Policy|Mexico City Policy]], reopened the [[LINK|lang_en|Keystone_XL|Keystone XL]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Dakota_Access_Pipeline|Dakota Access Pipeline]] construction projects and signed an executive order to begin planning, designing and constructing a [[LINK|lang_en|Mexico–United_States_barrier#Trump_administration|new Mexico border wall]] and reinforce border security. [[CITE|521|http://politico.com/agenda/story/2017/01/all-trump-executive-actions-000288]]

On January 31, Trump [[LINK|lang_en|Neil_Gorsuch_Supreme_Court_nomination|nominated]] U.S. Appeals Court judge [[LINK|lang_en|Neil_Gorsuch|Neil Gorsuch]] to fill the vacancy left on the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Supreme_Court|Supreme Court]] by the death of Justice [[LINK|lang_en|Antonin_Scalia|Antonin Scalia]]. [[CITE|739|https://washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-picks-colo-appeals-court-judge-neil-gorsuch-for-supreme-court/2017/01/31/2b08a226-e55e-11e6-a547-5fb9411d332c_story.html]] The Senate confirmed the nomination on April 7 with a 54–45 vote. [[CITE|969|https://archive.is/20170606001655/http://insider.foxnews.com/2017/04/07/neil-gorsuch-confirmation-vote-count-how-senators-voted-supreme-court-justice]]

caption.text: Trump campaigning in [[LINK|lang_en|Laconia,_New_Hampshire|Laconia, New Hampshire]], on July 16, 2015

items.text: Travel ban

On January 27, Trump signed [[LINK|lang_en|Executive_Order_13769|Executive Order 13769]], which suspended admission of refugees for 120 days and denied entry to citizens of [[LINK|lang_en|Iraq|Iraq]], [[LINK|lang_en|Iran|Iran]], [[LINK|lang_en|Libya|Libya]], [[LINK|lang_en|Somalia|Somalia]], [[LINK|lang_en|Sudan|Sudan]], [[LINK|lang_en|Syria|Syria]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Yemen|Yemen]] for 90 days, citing security concerns about terrorism. The order was imposed without warning and took effect immediately. [[CITE|90|http://bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-39183153]] Confusion and protests caused chaos at many airports, [[CITE|698|http://edition.cnn.com/2017/01/29/politics/us-immigration-protests]] as travelers were detained on arriving in the United States or barred from boarding U.S.-bound planes. [[CITE|918|https://theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/28/airports-us-immigration-ban-muslim-countries-trump]] The administration then clarified that visitors with a [[LINK|lang_en|Permanent_residence_(United_States)|green card]] were exempt from the ban. [[CITE|64|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/27/us/politics/trump-syrian-refugees.html]] [[CITE|289|https://mobile.nytimes.com/2017/01/29/us/politics/white-house-official-in-reversal-says-green-card-holders-wont-be-barred.html]]

On January 30, [[LINK|lang_en|Sally_Yates|Sally Yates]], the acting [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Attorney_General|Attorney General]], directed Justice Department lawyers not to defend the executive order and was promptly dismissed. [[CITE|546|https://whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/01/30/statement-appointment-dana-boente-acting-attorney-general]] She was replaced as acting Attorney General by [[LINK|lang_en|Dana_Boente|Dana Boente]], the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Attorney|U.S. Attorney]] for the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_District_Court_for_the_Eastern_District_of_Virginia|Eastern District of Virginia]], who agreed to enforce the order. [[CITE|756|https://nytimes.com/2017/01/30/us/politics/trump-immigration-ban-memo.html]] [[LINK|lang_en|Legal_challenges_to_Executive_Orders_13769_and_13780|Multiple legal challenges]] were filed against the order, and on February 5 a federal judge in Seattle blocked its implementation. [[CITE|248|http://irishtimes.com/news/world/us/few-rooting-for-donald-trump-on-his-mother-s-scottish-island-1.2663636]] [[CITE|91|https://nytimes.com/2017/02/05/us/politics/trumps-travel-ban.html]] On October 24, 2017, the Supreme Court dismissed the only remaining travel ban appeal as being moot because the revised order had expired. It expressed "no views on the merits" of the case. [[CITE|248|http://irishtimes.com/news/world/us/few-rooting-for-donald-trump-on-his-mother-s-scottish-island-1.2663636]]

On March 6, Trump issued a [[LINK|lang_en|Executive_Order_13780|revised order]], which excluded Iraq, gave specific exemptions for [[LINK|lang_en|Permanent_residence_(United_States)|permanent residents]], removed priorities for religious minorities (e.g. Christian refugees), and allowed for a week to implement legislation. [[CITE|509|http://foxnews.com/politics/2017/03/06/trump-signs-new-immigration-order-narrows-scope-travel-ban.html]] [[CITE|90|http://bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-39183153]] Again federal judges in Hawaii, Maryland and Virginia blocked its implementation. [[CITE|248|http://irishtimes.com/news/world/us/few-rooting-for-donald-trump-on-his-mother-s-scottish-island-1.2663636]] On June 26, 2017, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down the lower courts and allowed most provisions of the revised executive order to take effect. The Supreme Court ruled that Trump's ban can be enforced on visitors from targeted countries who lack a "credible claim of a *bona fide* relationship with a person or entity in the United States." [[CITE|922|http://chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-travel-ban-supreme-court-20170626-story.html]] The court scheduled full hearings in October. [[CITE|922|http://chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-travel-ban-supreme-court-20170626-story.html]]

On September 24, 2017, the temporary executive order, which was close to expiry, was replaced by [[LINK|lang_en|Presidential_Proclamation_9645|Presidential Proclamation 9645]], which permanently restricts travel from the originally targeted countries except Iraq and Sudan, and further bans travelers from North Korea, Chad, and Venezuela (only on certain government officials and their families). [[CITE|632|https://theguardian.com/us-news/2017/sep/25/trump-travel-ban-extended-to-blocks-on-north-korea-and-venezuela]] These provisions were slated to take effect on October 18, [[CITE|632|https://theguardian.com/us-news/2017/sep/25/trump-travel-ban-extended-to-blocks-on-north-korea-and-venezuela]] and the Supreme Court cancelled the hearing that was planned for October 10. [[CITE|248|http://irishtimes.com/news/world/us/few-rooting-for-donald-trump-on-his-mother-s-scottish-island-1.2663636]] On October 17, a federal judge in Hawaii blocked the portions of these provisions applying to the six Muslim-majority countries, leaving only the restrictions on North Korea and Venezuela to take effect. [[CITE|248|http://irishtimes.com/news/world/us/few-rooting-for-donald-trump-on-his-mother-s-scottish-island-1.2663636]]

caption.text: Trump rally in the [[LINK|lang_en|U.S._Bank_Arena|U.S. Bank Arena]], [[LINK|lang_en|Cincinnati,_Ohio|Cincinnati, Ohio]], on October 13, 2016

items.text: Dismissal of James Comey

On May 9, 2017, Trump dismissed FBI Director [[LINK|lang_en|James_Comey|James Comey]]. He attributed the action to recommendations from Attorney General [[LINK|lang_en|Jeff_Sessions|Jeff Sessions]] and [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Deputy_Attorney_General|Deputy AG]] [[LINK|lang_en|Rod_Rosenstein|Rod Rosenstein]], [[CITE|696|https://nytimes.com/2017/05/09/us/politics/james-comey-fired-fbi.html]] which criticized Comey's conduct in the investigation about [[LINK|lang_en|Hillary_Clinton_email_controversy#October_2016_–_Additional_investigation|Hillary Clinton's emails]]. [[CITE|942|https://theguardian.com/us-news/2017/may/09/james-comey-fbi-fired-donald-trump]] On May 11, Trump stated that he was concerned with the ongoing "Russia thing"[[CITE|135|https://washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/trump-says-fbi-director-comey-told-him-three-times-he-wasnt-under-investigation-once-in-a-phone-call-initiated-by-the-president/2017/05/11/2b384c9a-3669-11e7-b4ee-434b6d506b37_story.html]] and that he had intended to fire Comey earlier. [[CITE|381|http://theweek.com/speedreads/698368/president-trump-just-completely-contradicted-official-white-house-account-comey-firing]]

According to a [[LINK|lang_en|Comey_memo|Comey memo]] of a private conversation on February 14, 2017, Trump said he "hoped" Comey would drop the investigation into [[LINK|lang_en|Michael_Flynn|Michael Flynn]], [[CITE|638|https://wsj.com/articles/trump-asked-comey-to-drop-flynn-investigation-according-to-memo-written-by-former-fbi-director-1494974774]] who had been forced to resign as [[LINK|lang_en|National_Security_Advisor|National Security Advisor]] after it was discovered that he had misled the Vice President about communications with Russian ambassador [[LINK|lang_en|Sergey_Kislyak|Sergey Kislyak]].

In March and April, Trump had told Comey that the ongoing suspicions formed a "cloud" impairing his presidency, [[CITE|833|https://www.intelligence.senate.gov/sites/default/files/documents/os-jcomey-060817.pdf]] and asked him to publicly state that he was not personally under investigation.

[[CITE|396|https://nytimes.com/2017/06/07/us/politics/james-comey-statement-testimony.html]] He also asked [[LINK|lang_en|Director_of_National_Intelligence|DNI]] [[LINK|lang_en|Dan_Coats|Dan Coats]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Director_of_the_National_Security_Agency|NSA Director]] [[LINK|lang_en|Michael_S._Rogers|Michael Rogers]] to issue statements saying there was no evidence that his campaign colluded with Russia during the 2016 election. [[CITE|639|http://edition.cnn.com/2017/05/22/politics/donald-trump-intelligence-community/index.html]] Both refused, considering this an inappropriate request, although not illegal. [[CITE|858|http://nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-asked-top-intel-officials-push-back-publicly-russia-probe-n763336]] Comey eventually testified on June 8 that while he was director, the FBI investigations did not target Trump himself. [[CITE|833|https://www.intelligence.senate.gov/sites/default/files/documents/os-jcomey-060817.pdf]] [[CITE|1051|https://nytimes.com/2017/06/08/us/politics/trump-speech-faith-freedom-coalition.html]] *The Washington Post* later reported that within days of Comey's dismissal, the FBI started investigating whether Trump had obstructed justice. [[CITE|169|https://washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/06/15/the-president-is-under-investigation-for-obstruction-of-justice-how-did-we-get-here]] Trump's lawyer [[LINK|lang_en|Jay_Sekulow|Jay Sekulow]] stated that he had not been notified of any such investigation. [[CITE|360|http://cbsnews.com/news/transcript-jay-sekulow-on-face-the-nation-june-18-2017]] ABC News later reported that the special counsel is gathering preliminary information about possible obstruction of justice but has not launched a full-scale investigation. [[CITE|602|http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/things-stand-special-counsel-muellers-russia-probe/story?id=48142304]]
Trump attracted attention for implying that he had "tapes" of conversations with Comey, before later stating that he did not in fact have such tapes.
[[CITE|813|https://nytimes.com/2017/06/22/us/politics/trump-comey-tapes.html]]
False and misleading statements
As president, Trump has frequently made false statements in public speeches and remarks.

[[CITE|1013|https://nytimes.com/2017/04/29/us/politics/fact-checking-president-trump-through-his-first-100-days.html]] [[CITE|493|https://washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2017/05/01/president-trumps-first-100-days-the-fact-check-tally]] [[CITE|1076|https://nytimes.com/2017/06/22/us/politics/factcheck-donald-trump-iowa-rally.html]] Trump uttered "at least one false or misleading claim per day on 91 of his first 99 days" in office according to *The New York Times*, [[CITE|1013|https://nytimes.com/2017/04/29/us/politics/fact-checking-president-trump-through-his-first-100-days.html]] and 1,318 total in his first 263 days in office according to the "Fact Checker" political analysis column of *The Washington Post*, [[CITE|238|https://washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2017/10/10/president-trump-has-made-1318-false-or-misleading-claims-over-263-days]] which also wrote, "President Trump is the most fact-challenged politician that The Fact Checker has ever encountered... the pace and volume of the president's misstatements means that we cannot possibly keep up." [[CITE|493|https://washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2017/05/01/president-trumps-first-100-days-the-fact-check-tally]]
Domestic policy
Energy

Trump's energy policy advocates domestic industrial support for both fossil and renewable energy sources in order to curb reliance on Middle-Eastern oil and possibly turn the U.S. into a net energy exporter.

[[CITE|539|https://donaldjtrump.com/press-releases/an-america-first-energy-plan]] [[LINK|lang_en|Political_appointments_of_Donald_Trump|His appointed advisers]] favor a less regulated energy market and, because they do not consider [[LINK|lang_en|Climate_change|climate change]] a threat, see no need for immediate action. [[CITE|746|https://washingtonpost.com/business/economy/trumps-energy-policy-team-includes-climate-change-skeptic-free-market-advocate/2016/11/29/86e52004-b5a4-11e6-b8df-600bd9d38a02_story.html]]
Climate change

Trump does not accept the [[LINK|lang_en|Scientific_consensus_on_climate_change|scientific consensus on climate change]]. [[CITE|984|https://nytimes.com/2016/05/27/us/politics/donald-trump-global-warming-energy-policy.html]] [[CITE|165|https://washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2016/03/22/donald-trumps-unsettling-nonsense-on-weather-and-climate]] In 2012, he said that [[LINK|lang_en|Global_warming|global warming]] was a hoax invented by the Chinese, but later said that he was joking. [[CITE|408|https://washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2015/07/22/heres-what-donald-trump-really-believes]] [[CITE|1072|http://politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/jan/24/bernie-s/yes-donald-trump-really-did-tweet-climate-change-h]] He has called the [[LINK|lang_en|EPA|Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)]] a "disgrace" and has threatened to cut its budget. Trump pledged to eliminate the [[LINK|lang_en|Clean_Power_Plan|Clean Power Plan]] [[CITE|531|https://wsj.com/articles/trump-can-ax-the-clean-power-plan-by-executive-order-1479679923]] and withdraw from the [[LINK|lang_en|Paris_Agreement|Paris Climate Agreement]], which calls for reductions in carbon emissions in more than 170 countries. [[CITE|852|http://lcv.org/assets/docs/presidential-candidates-on.pdf]] After winning the presidency, Trump said he had an "open mind" towards the Paris agreement, [[CITE|1090|https://theatlantic.com/science/archive/2016/11/what-does-trump-think-about-climate-change-he-doesnt-know-either/508541]] but on June 1, 2017, he announced that [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_withdrawal_from_the_Paris_Agreement|the United States would withdraw from the Paris agreement]], making the United States one of only three nations at the time, besides Syria and Nicaragua, not to be members. [[CITE|252|http://cnn.com/2017/06/01/politics/trump-paris-climate-decision/index.html]]
Immigration
Trump's immigration policies were intensely discussed during the campaign.

Trump vowed to build a more substantial [[LINK|lang_en|Mexico–United_States_barrier|wall]] on the [[LINK|lang_en|Mexico–United_States_border|Mexico–United States border]] to keep out [[LINK|lang_en|Illegal_immigrants|illegal immigrants]], a wall that Trump promised Mexico would pay for. [[CITE|618|https://washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/05/13/trump-all-policy-proposals-are-just-flexible-suggestions]] [[CITE|703|https://news.vice.com/story/the-us-already-has-a-border-wall-and-its-basically-useless]] [[CITE|880|http://politico.com/story/2016/12/trump-religious-dealmaking-dividends-232277]] He pledged to massively deport [[LINK|lang_en|Illegal_immigrant_population_of_the_United_States|illegal immigrants residing in the United States]], [[CITE|707|http://cbc.ca/news/world/donald-trump-emphasizes-plans-to-build-real-wall-at-mexico-border-1.3196807]] and criticized [[LINK|lang_en|Birthright_citizenship_in_the_United_States|birthright citizenship]] as it creates "[[LINK|lang_en|Anchor_babies|anchor babies]]". [[CITE|880|http://politico.com/story/2016/12/trump-religious-dealmaking-dividends-232277]] He said the focus of deportation would be criminals, those who have overstayed their visas, and other "security threats". [[CITE|880|http://politico.com/story/2016/12/trump-religious-dealmaking-dividends-232277]]

Following the [[LINK|lang_en|November_2015_Paris_attacks|November 2015 Paris attacks]], Trump made a controversial proposal to completely ban Muslim non-citizens from entering the United States until stronger vetting systems could be implemented. [[CITE|880|http://politico.com/story/2016/12/trump-religious-dealmaking-dividends-232277]] [[CITE|937|https://nytimes.com/2015/12/16/upshot/how-unpopular-is-trumps-muslim-ban-depends-how-you-ask.html]] [[CITE|880|http://politico.com/story/2016/12/trump-religious-dealmaking-dividends-232277]] Later in 2016 he stated that the ban would apply only to people originating from countries with a "proven history of terrorism against the United States or its allies", or countries "compromised by terrorism". [[CITE|409|http://chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-donald-trump-muslim-ban-20160625-story.html]] [[CITE|880|http://politico.com/story/2016/12/trump-religious-dealmaking-dividends-232277]] [[CITE|880|http://politico.com/story/2016/12/trump-religious-dealmaking-dividends-232277]]

Shortly after coming into office, Trump issued a limited, which was [[LINK|lang_en|Legal_challenges_to_Executive_Orders_13769_and_13780|suspended by federal courts]] and eventually came into effect following a June 2017 Supreme Court decision. [[CITE|922|http://chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-travel-ban-supreme-court-20170626-story.html]]
Social issues

Trump is conservative, describes himself as [[LINK|lang_en|Pro-life|pro-life]], and generally opposes abortion; exceptions are made in cases of rape, incest, and circumstances endangering the health of the mother. [[CITE|84|http://cnn.com/2016/04/21/politics/donald-trump-republican-platform-abortion]] He has said that he is committed to appointing justices who would try to overturn the ruling in *[[LINK|lang_en|Roe_v._Wade|Roe v. Wade]] *. [[CITE|558|http://video.foxbusiness.com/v/4598495569001]] He personally supports "traditional marriage"[[CITE|408|https://washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2015/07/22/heres-what-donald-trump-really-believes]] but considers the [[LINK|lang_en|Same-sex_marriage_in_the_United_States|nationwide legality]] of [[LINK|lang_en|Same-sex_marriage|same-sex marriage]] a "settled" issue. [[CITE|558|http://video.foxbusiness.com/v/4598495569001]]

Trump supports a broad interpretation of the [[LINK|lang_en|Second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution|Second Amendment]] and says he is opposed to [[LINK|lang_en|Gun_control|gun control]] in general, [[CITE|946|http://newsweek.com/brief-history-donald-trumps-stance-gun-rights-461705]] [[CITE|500|https://donaldjtrump.com/positions/second-amendment-rights]] although his views have shifted over time. [[CITE|417|http://cnn.com/2016/06/20/politics/donald-trump-gun-positions-nra-orlando]] Trump opposes [[LINK|lang_en|Legality_of_cannabis_by_U.S._jurisdiction|legalizing recreational marijuana]] but supports legalizing [[LINK|lang_en|Medical_cannabis|medical marijuana]]. [[CITE|542|http://c-span.org/video?c4541840%2Fdonald-trump-marijuana=]] He favors [[LINK|lang_en|Capital_punishment_in_the_United_States|capital punishment]], [[CITE|804|http://cnn.com/2015/12/10/politics/donald-trump-police-officers-death-penalty]] as well as the use of [[LINK|lang_en|Waterboarding|waterboarding]]. [[CITE|543|http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/video/ted-cruz-donald-trump-advocate-bringing-back-waterboarding-36764410]]
Health care

In 1999, Trump told *[[LINK|lang_en|Larry_King_Live|Larry King Live]] * that "I believe in universal healthcare." [[CITE|926|http://politifact.com/wisconsin/statements/2015/sep/11/reid-ribble/donald-trump-wants-replace-obamacare-single-payer-]] Trump's 2000 book, *The America We Deserve*, argued strongly for a [[LINK|lang_en|Single-payer_healthcare|single-payer healthcare]] system based on the [[LINK|lang_en|Healthcare_in_Canada|Canadian model]], [[CITE|1084|https://books.google.com/books?id=PV6qZU_xev8C&pg=PT258]] and has voiced admiration for the [[LINK|lang_en|NHS_Scotland|Scottish National Health Service]]. [[CITE|926|http://politifact.com/wisconsin/statements/2015/sep/11/reid-ribble/donald-trump-wants-replace-obamacare-single-payer-]] [[CITE|741|http://cnn.com/2015/07/18/politics/trump-has-never-sought-forgiveness]] [[CITE|741|http://cnn.com/2015/07/18/politics/trump-has-never-sought-forgiveness]]

As a candidate, Trump repeatedly vowed to repeal and replace [[LINK|lang_en|Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act|Obamacare]]. [[CITE|650|http://npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/11/09/501203831/trump-can-kill-obamacare-with-or-without-help-from-congress]] [[CITE|791|http://cnn.com/2017/01/10/politics/paul-ryan-obamacare-repeal-and-replace/index.html]] Starting early in his presidency he urged Congress to repeal and replace it. In May the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_House_of_Representatives|United States House of Representatives]] voted to repeal the ACA. [[CITE|741|http://cnn.com/2015/07/18/politics/trump-has-never-sought-forgiveness]] However, despite trying for months, the Senate was unable to pass any of several versions of a repeal bill. [[CITE|741|http://cnn.com/2015/07/18/politics/trump-has-never-sought-forgiveness]] Trump has expressed a desire to "let Obamacare fail", and the Trump administration has cut the ACA enrollment period in half and drastically reduced funding for advertising and other ways to encourage enrollment. [[CITE|741|http://cnn.com/2015/07/18/politics/trump-has-never-sought-forgiveness]] [[CITE|540|http://huffingtonpost.ca/entry/trump-obamacare-sabotage-enrollment-cuts_us_59a87bffe4b0b5e530fd5751]] [[CITE|809|http://politico.com/story/2017/08/31/trump-obamacare-outreach-cuts-242225]]

Trump aims to streamline the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Department_of_Veterans_Affairs|Department of Veterans Affairs]], getting rid of [[LINK|lang_en|Veterans_Health_Administration_scandal_of_2014|backlogs and waitlists]], and upgrading relevant facilities. [[CITE|1029|http://militarytimes.com/articles/2017-watch-trump-va-reforms]] On his first Monday in office, Trump issued a federal hiring freeze on the VA. [[CITE|195|https://usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/24/trump-hiring-freeze-includes-veterans-affairs/96999464]]
Education

Trump has stated his support for [[LINK|lang_en|School_choice|school choice]] and local control for primary and secondary schools. [[CITE|1024|http://americanprinciplesinaction.org/apia-education/education/school-choice/donald-trump-on-school-choice]] He opposes the [[LINK|lang_en|Common_Core_State_Standards_Initiative|Common Core State Standards Initiative]] for primary and secondary schools, [[CITE|1059|http://foxnews.com/politics/2015/06/16/trump-sets-record-for-longest-2016-gop-announcement-speech]] and has called it "a disaster" that must be ended. [[CITE|895|http://slate.com/blogs/schooled/2016/01/26/donald_trump_releases_education_video_condemns_common_core.html]] He has stated he would abolish all or part of the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Department_of_Education|Department of Education]]. [[CITE|1114|http://nationalreview.com/corner/425991/why-not-abolish-department-education-jason-richwine]]
Economy and trade

Trump's campaign tax plan called for levelling the [[LINK|lang_en|Corporate_tax_in_the_United_States#Tax_rates|corporate tax rate]] to 15%, eliminating various business loopholes and deductions, [[CITE|107|https://donaldjtrump.com/positions/tax-reform]] and reducing the number of brackets for personal income tax: the top rate would be reduced from 39.6% to 25%, a large "zero bracket" would be created, and the [[LINK|lang_en|Alternative_minimum_tax|alternative minimum tax]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Estate_tax|estate tax]] (which currently applies to individual estates over $5.45 million or $10.9 million per married couple) would both be eliminated. [[CITE|271|http://taxfoundation.org/article/details-and-analysis-donald-trump-s-tax-plan]] His comments about the [[LINK|lang_en|Minimum_wage_in_the_United_States|minimum wage]] have been inconsistent. [[CITE|522|http://politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/may/19/donald-trump/donald-trump-wrong-elizabeth-warren-lied-saying-he]] [[CITE|772|http://politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/jul/26/bernie-s/sanders-trump-would-allow-states-lower-minimum-wag]] [[CITE|141|http://cnn.com/2016/01/20/politics/donald-trump-tony-perkins-sarah-palin/index.html]]

Trump identifies as a "[[LINK|lang_en|Free_trade|free trader]]", but says that trade must be "reasonably fair". He has often been called a "[[LINK|lang_en|Protectionist|protectionist]]", [[CITE|141|http://cnn.com/2016/01/20/politics/donald-trump-tony-perkins-sarah-palin/index.html]] [[CITE|141|http://cnn.com/2016/01/20/politics/donald-trump-tony-perkins-sarah-palin/index.html]] [[CITE|141|http://cnn.com/2016/01/20/politics/donald-trump-tony-perkins-sarah-palin/index.html]] because of his criticism of [[LINK|lang_en|NAFTA|NAFTA]], [[CITE|141|http://cnn.com/2016/01/20/politics/donald-trump-tony-perkins-sarah-palin/index.html]] [[CITE|141|http://cnn.com/2016/01/20/politics/donald-trump-tony-perkins-sarah-palin/index.html]] the [[LINK|lang_en|Trans-Pacific_Partnership|Trans-Pacific Partnership]] (TPP), [[CITE|74|http://latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-japan-trump-president-20160625-snap-story.html]] and his proposal to significantly raise tariffs on Chinese and Mexican exports to the United States. [[CITE|141|http://cnn.com/2016/01/20/politics/donald-trump-tony-perkins-sarah-palin/index.html]] [[CITE|141|http://cnn.com/2016/01/20/politics/donald-trump-tony-perkins-sarah-palin/index.html]] He has also been critical of the [[LINK|lang_en|World_Trade_Organization|World Trade Organization]], threatening to leave unless his proposed tariffs are accepted. [[CITE|222|http://telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/us-election/12107003/Donald-Trump-faces-questions-over-Two-Corinthians.html]] [[CITE|222|http://telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/us-election/12107003/Donald-Trump-faces-questions-over-Two-Corinthians.html]] However, Trump has been very keen to support a "fair" post-[[LINK|lang_en|Brexit|Brexit]] trade deal with the United Kingdom, [[CITE|222|http://telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/us-election/12107003/Donald-Trump-faces-questions-over-Two-Corinthians.html]] which Trump says would be "good for both sides". [[CITE|222|http://telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/us-election/12107003/Donald-Trump-faces-questions-over-Two-Corinthians.html]]
Government size and deregulation

Trump's early policies have favored [[LINK|lang_en|Deregulation|deregulation]] and a smaller federal government. He became the first president in sixteen years to sign a [[LINK|lang_en|Congressional_Review_Act|Congressional Review Act]] disapproval resolution; the law had been used only once before. [[CITE|222|http://telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/us-election/12107003/Donald-Trump-faces-questions-over-Two-Corinthians.html]] During his first six weeks in office, he abolished ninety federal regulations. [[CITE|222|http://telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/us-election/12107003/Donald-Trump-faces-questions-over-Two-Corinthians.html]] [[CITE|222|http://telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/us-election/12107003/Donald-Trump-faces-questions-over-Two-Corinthians.html]]

On January 23, 2017, Trump ordered a [[LINK|lang_en|2017_United_States_federal_hiring_freeze|temporary government-wide hiring freeze]], which allows for exceptions, primarily for jobs deemed vital for national security or public safety reasons.
